title: Updating Vulnerability Feed in Airgapped Environments
body: Restart the pod feeds-api

title: Updating Vulnerability Feed in Airgapped Environments
body: The following script (feeds_database_update.sh) performs the five steps:

title: Updating Vulnerability Feed in Airgapped Environments
body:
#!/bin/bash
QUAY_USERNAME="<change_me>"
QUAY_PASSWORD="<change_me>"

# Download image
docker login quay.io/sysdig -u ${QUAY_USERNAME} -p ${QUAY_PASSWORD}
docker image pull quay.io/sysdig/vuln-feed-database:latest
# Save image
docker image save quay.io/sysdig/vuln-feed-database:latest -o vuln-feed-database.tar
# Optionally move image
mv vuln-feed-database.tar /var/shared-folder
# Load image remotely
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "docker image load -i /var/shared-folder/vuln-feed-database.tar"
# Push image remotely
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "docker tag vuln-feed-database:latest airgapped-registry/vuln-feed-database:latest"
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "docker image push airgapped-registry/vuln-feed-database:latest"
# Restart database pod
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "kubectl -n sysdigcloud scale deploy sysdigcloud-feeds-db --replicas=0"
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "kubectl -n sysdigcloud scale deploy sysdigcloud-feeds-db --replicas=1"
# Restart feeds-api pod
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "kubectl -n sysdigcloud scale deploy sysdigcloud-feeds-api --replicas=0"
ssh -t user@airgapped-host "kubectl -n sysdigcloud scale deploy sysdigcloud-feeds-api --replicas=1"

title: Updating Vulnerability Feed in Airgapped Environments
body: Schedule a chron job to run the script on a chosen schedule (e.g. every day):

title: Updating Vulnerability Feed in Airgapped Environments
body: 0 8 * * * feeds-database-update.sh >/dev/null 2>&1

apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body: Sysdig provides the necessary scripts, images, and .yaml files in a GitHub repository. The first step is to clone those files and check out the latest version. (These examples use 1234.)

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body: Find the current release tag from https://github.com/draios/sysdigcloud-kubernetes/releases/latest.

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body: Run the command:

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body:
git clone https://github.com/draios/sysdigcloud-kubernetes.git
cd sysdigcloud-kubernetes
git checkout tags/<1234>

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body: Create a namespace called sysdigcloud:

title: Download the Source Files to a New Namespace
body: kubectl create namespace sysdigcloud

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: Create a TCP load balancer (i.e., AWS NLB) that forwards ports 80, 443, 6443 to the Kubernetes worker nodes, with a healthcheck to /healthz on port 10253.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: This can be done in three ways:

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: Use an existing external load balancer. Sysdig relies heavily on DNS; you need a DNS record pointing to the load balancer.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: Create a load balancer in your cloud provider. (For example in AWS, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/create-network-load-balancer.html.) You need a DNS record that points to the load balancer. This is the fully qualified domain name required later in the config.yaml, api-ingress.yaml and/or api-ingress-with-secure.yaml.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: Create a yaml with the following content and apply it to the sysdigcloud namespace. This automatically creates a load balancer in the cloud provider environment, with an external DNS name.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: This is the fully qualified domain name required later in the config.yaml, api-ingress.yaml and/or api-ingress-with-secure.yaml.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body:
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
 name: haproxy-ingress-lb-service
spec:
 type: LoadBalancer
 ports:
 - name: http
 port: 80
 targetPort: 80
 - name: https
 port: 443
 targetPort: 443
 - name: https2
 port: 6443
 targetPort: 6443
 selector:
 run: haproxy-ingress

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: Apply the changes to the sysdigcloud namespace.

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: kubectl -n sysdigcloud apply -f <yourlbfile.yamlservice.yaml>

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: To get the DNS name, run the command:

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: $ kubectl get svc -o wide -n sysdigcloud

title: Add External Load Balancer
body: The output shows the External-IP (DNS name):

title: Add External Load Balancer
body:
NAME TYPE CLUSTER-IP EXTERNAL-IP PORT(S) AGE SELECTOR
haproxy-ingress-lb-service LoadBalancer 100.66.118.183 sample123.us-east-1.elb.amazonaws.com 80:31688/TCP,443:32324/TCP,6443:30668/TCP 1d run=haproxy-ingress

title: DNS Entry (For Test Environments without a Load Balancer)
body: Not for production environments.

title: DNS Entry (For Test Environments without a Load Balancer)
body: Create a DNS entry for your Sysdig install using the fully qualified domain name that contains all the external IPs as A records. This will use DNS round-robin to load balance your clients to the Kubernetes cluster.

body: To set this up, you must:

title: To Disable SSL between Agent and Collector
body: To disable SSL between agents and collectors, set JVM options when configuring backend components.

title: To Create Self-Signed Certs
body: Run these commands (edit to add your API_DNS_NAME and COLLECTOR_DNS_NAME):

title: To Create Self-Signed Certs
body:
openssl req -new -newkey rsa:2048 -days 3650 -nodes -x509 -subj "/C=US/ST=CA/L=SanFrancisco/O=ICT/CN=<API_DNS_NAME>" -keyout server.key -out server.crt
openssl req -new -newkey rsa:2048 -days 3650 -nodes -x509 -subj "/C=US/ST=CA/L=SanFrancisco/O=ICT/CN=<COLLECTOR_DNS_NAME>" -keyout collector.key -out collector.crt

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets
body: This uses two different certificates, one for the API/UI, and one for the collector.

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets
body:
kubectl -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret --cert=server.crt --key=server.key
kubectl -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret-collector --cert=collector.crt --key=collector.key

body: If the signing authorities for the certificates presented by these services are not well-known to the Sysdig Platform (e.g., if you maintain your own Certificate Authority), they are not trusted by default.

title: Manual Install (OpenShift)
body: As of Sysdig Platform v 2.5.0, a semi-automated install option is available and is preferred.

title: Manual Install (OpenShift)
body: This section describes how to install the backend components of the Sysdig platform using an existing OpenShift cluster. It applies to backend versions 1929 and higher. See Installer (Kubernetes | OpenShift) 3.5.0.

title: Introduction
body: The Sysdig platform includes both Sysdig Monitor and Sysdig Secure, which are licensed separately. All installations include Sysdig Monitor, while some of the Secure components are installed and configured as additional steps within the overall installation process. When installing the Sysdig platform on OpenShift manually, you will install each backend component with separate oc commands.

body: Prerequisites

body: Two items from your Sysdig purchase-confirmation email:

title: DNS Preparation
body: If you want more information on OpenShift's DNS requirements; see the OpenShift documentation.

title: DNS Preparation
body: Option 1: DNS without Wildcard

title: DNS Preparation
body: You need to request two different DNS records from your DNS team: one for the Sysdig API/UI and another for the Sysdig collector. These records should point to your infrastructure nodes and are the two routes that will be exposed, i.e., sysdig.api.example.com and sysdig.collector.example.com.

title: DNS Preparation
body: Option 2: DNS with Wildcard

title: DNS Preparation
body: With wildcard DNS, you do not have to make an official request from the DNS team. Your implementation team can pick any two DNS names to use for the API/UI and Collector. These will be exposed to the infrastructure nodes once the configuration is completed. (i.e. sysdig.api.example.com and sysdig.collector.example.com.)

title: SSL Certificate Preparation
body: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend discusses how to implement SSL; decide ahead of time whether you will use SSL with wildcard or without.

title: SSL Certificate Preparation
body: SSL with Wildcard

title: SSL Certificate Preparation
body: With wildcard SSL, you use the same certificate for both the API and the collector.

title: SSL Certificate Preparation
body: SSL without Wildcard

title: SSL Certificate Preparation
body: You need two SSL certs, one for each DNS record.

title: Consider Elasticsearch Default Privileges
body: By default, the Elasticsearch container will be installed in privileged (root-access) mode. This mode is only needed so the container can reconfigure the hosts' Linux file descriptors if necessary. See Elasticsearch's description here.

title: Consider Elasticsearch Default Privileges
body: If you prefer not to allow Elasticsearch to run with root access to the host, you will need to:

title: Consider Elasticsearch Default Privileges
body: Set your own file descriptors on all Linux hosts in the Kubernetes cluster.

title: Consider Elasticsearch Default Privileges
body: If one host were to go down, Kubernetes could choose a different node for Elasticsearch, so each Linux host must have the file descriptors set.

title: Consider Elasticsearch Default Privileges
body: Set privileged:false in the elasticsearch-statefulset.yaml file.

title: Step 1 Download and Unpack the Latest Release

title: Step 1 Download and Unpack the Latest Release
body: The source link has the format: https://github.com/draios/sysdigcloud-kubernetes/archive/<v1234>.tar.gz. To unpack it, run the following commands (replacing version number as appropriate):

wget https://github.com/draios/sysdigcloud-kubernetes/archive/<v1234>.tar.gz
tar zxf <1234>.tar.gz
cd sysdigcloud-kubernetes-<1234>

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: The ConfigMap (config.yaml) is populated with information about usernames, passwords, SSL certs, and various application-specific settings.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: The steps below give the minimum edits that should be performed in a test environment.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: Add your license key:

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

# Required: Sysdig Cloud license

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: Change the super admin name and password, which are the super admin credentials for the entire system. See here for details.Find the Super Admin Credentials and API Token

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: Find the settings in config.yaml here:

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

sysdigcloud.default.user: test@sysdig.com
 # Required: Sysdig Cloud super admin user password

 sysdigcloud.default.user.password: test

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: Edit the collector endpoint and API URL:Change the placeholder to point to the DNS names you have established for Sysdig.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: Remember that you must have defined one name for the collector and another for the API URL.

body: Note: Change the collector port to 443.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

collector.endpoint: <COLLECTOR_DNS_NAME>
collector.port: "443"
api.url: https://<API_DNS_NAME>:443

body: Recommended: edit the file to set the JVM options for Cassandra, Elasticsearch, and API, worker, and collector as well.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components
body: For installations over 100 agents, it is recommended to allocate 8 GB of heap per JVM.

title: Step 2: Configure Backend Components

cassandra.jvm.options: "-Xms8G -Xmx8G"
 elasticsearch.jvm.options: "-Xms8G -Xmx8G"

 sysdigcloud.jvm.worker.options: "-Xms4G -Xmx8G"

elasticsearch.jvm.options: "-Xms8G -Xmx8G"

sysdigcloud.jvm.worker.options: "-Xms8G -Xmx8G -Ddraios.agents.installParams.sslEnabled=false"
sysdigcloud.jvm.collector.options: "-Xms8G -Xmx8G -Ddraios.agents.installParams.sslEnabled=false"

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: SSL-secured communication is used between user browsers and the Sysdig API server(s), and between the Sysdig agent and the collectors.

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: To set this up, you must:

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: Use an existing wildcard SSL certificate and key, or

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: Use existing standard certs for API and collector, or

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: Create self-signed certificates and keys for API and collector

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: If you are not using wildcard SSL, you have to use two separate certificates, one for API URL and one for the collector.

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: To disable SSL between agent and collector:

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: To disable SSL between agent and collectors, you set a JVM option when configuring backend components (below).

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: To create self-signed certs:

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: Run these commands (edit to add your API_DNS_NAME and COLLECTOR_DNS_NAME):

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body:
openssl req -new -newkey rsa:2048 -days 3650 -nodes -x509 -subj "/C=US/ST=CA/L=SanFrancisco/O=ICT/CN=<API_DNS_NAME>" -keyout server.key -out server.crt
openssl req -new -newkey rsa:2048 -days 3650 -nodes -x509 -subj "/C=US/ST=CA/L=SanFrancisco/O=ICT/CN=<COLLECTOR_DNS_NAME>" -keyout collector.key -out collector.crt

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: To use an existing wildcard cert:

title: Step 5: Set Up SSL Connectivity to the Backend
body: Obtain the respective server.crt and server.key files.

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: With Wildcard

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: Uses the same certificate for both the API/UI and the collector.

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: Run these commands:

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs

oc -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret --cert=server.crt --key=server.key
oc -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret-collector --cert=server.crt --key=server.key

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: Without Wildcard

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: Uses two different certificates, one for the API/UI, and one for the collector.

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body: Run these commands:

title: To Create Kubernetes Secrets for the Certs
body:
oc -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret --cert=server.crt --key=server.key
oc -n sysdigcloud create secret tls sysdigcloud-ssl-secret-collector --cert=collector.crt --key=collector.key

title: Edit storageClassName Parameters

title: Edit storageClassName Parameters
body: If no storage class has been defined, create a manifest for one, and then deploy it.

title: Edit storageClassName Parameters
body: For example, a manifest could be named sysdigcloud-storageclass.yaml and contain the following contents (for a storage class using GP2 volumes in AWS):

title: Edit storageClassName Parameters

apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
 name: gp2
 labels:
 kubernetes.io/cluster-service: "true"
 addonmanager.kubernetes.io/mode: EnsureExists
provisioner: kubernetes.io/aws-ebs
parameters:
 type: gp2

title: To Make Configuration Changes
body: Replace kubectl with oc for OpenShift.

title: Update the Config Map
body: There are two ways to change the original installation parameters in the config map: edit or overwrite.

title: Update the Config Map
body: To edit the config map, run the following command:

title: Update the Config Map
body: kubectl edit configmap/sysdigcloud-config --namespace sysdigcloud

title: Update the Config Map
body: A text editor is presented with the config map to be edited. Enter parameters as needed, then save and quit.

title: Update the Config Map
body: Then restart the config map (below).

title: Update the Config Map
body: To overwrite the config map that is edited on the client-side, (e.g. to keep it synced in a git repository), use the following command:

title: Update the Config Map
body: kubectl replace -f sysdigcloud/config.yaml --namespace sysdigcloud

title: Update the Config Map
body: Then restart the config map (below).

title: Restart Configmap
body: After updating the configmap, the Sysdig components must be restarted for the changed parameters to take effect. This can be done by forcing a rolling update of the deployments.

title: Restart Configmap
body: A possible way to do so is to change something innocuous, which forces a rolling update. E.g.:

title: Restart Configmap
body:
kubectl -n sysdigcloud patch deployment [deploymnet] -p \
 "{\"spec\":{\"template\":{\"metadata\":{\"annotations\":{\"date\":\"$(date +'%s')\"}}}}}"

body: Replace kubectl with oc for OpenShift.

body: Sysdig will deprecate support for Replicated installs in the coming months. If you are a new customer considering installing with Replicated, please contact Sysdig support.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: When planning an on-premises installation, the following choice points must be decided upon.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Infrastructure Managers: To install Sysdig on-premises, administrators choose one of two infrastructure managers:

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Kubernetes (see Installer (KubernetesOpenShift), orInstaller (KubernetesOpenShift)

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Replicated: an easy-to-use orchestrator that includes a GUI management tool.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: This guide describes how to install the Replicated client and use it to install and manage the Sysdig platform.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Single-Host or Multi-Host Install: For test or proof-of-concept installations, a single-host install will include all components; for production, a distributed environment is needed.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Airgapped or non-airgapped environment:

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: If your environment is accessible to the Internet during the install process, then the installation options include both script-based or GUI-based.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: In airgapped environments (no Internet access), you must download components into your airgapped repository, and can only use the GUI-based installation.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: See Airgapped Installation.Airgapped Installation

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Where to put the Replicated Management Console: When installing on-premises using Replicated as the orchestrator, the following Replicated components will be installed on your system:

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Replicated UI (on a host you designate to host the Replicated Management Console)

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Replicated retraced containers that handle logging (on the Management Console host only)

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Replicated operator component (will go on all hosts)

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: In a multi-host installation, one server will be the Replicated Management Console host. The system load for these components is minor.

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: No matter which installation options you choose, you will use the Replicated GUI post-installation to:

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Start/stop Sysdig components

title: Understand the Choice Points
body: Upgrade Sysdig backend components

title: Collect Troubleshooting Data
body: When experiencing issues, you can collect troubleshooting data that can help the support team. The data can be collected by hand, or Sysdig provides a very simple get_support_bundle.sh script that takes as an argument the namespace where Sysdig is deployed and will generate a tarball containing some information (mostly log files). The script is located in the GitHub repository: https://github.com/draios/sysdigcloud-kubernetes. (See also Get Help | Using Sysdig Support (On-Prem).)

title: Collect Troubleshooting Data
body:
$ ./scripts/get_support_bundle.sh sysdigcloud
Getting support logs for sysdigcloud-api-1477528018-4od59
Getting support logs for sysdigcloud-api-1477528018-ach89

title: Docker Connectivity Issues (IPv4/IPv6)
body: IP packet forwarding is governed by the ip_forward system parameter. Packets can only pass between containers if this parameter is 1. Usually, you will simply leave the Docker server at its default setting --ip-forward=trueand Docker will go set ip_forward to 1 for you when the server starts up. If you set --ip-forward=false and your system’s kernel has it enabled, the --ip-forward=false option has no effect.

title: File Write Permissions Issues (SELINUX or APP ARMOR)
body: During the install, you may see errors writing to volumes such as (/var or /opt) from either the onprem install scripts or Docker. You should disable SELINUX (CENTOS/RHEL) or Apparmor (UBUNTU/DEBIAN) during the course of the install so the valid directories can be created. This can be accomplished by:

title: File Write Permissions Issues (SELINUX or APP ARMOR)
body: Centos (SELINUX)

title: File Write Permissions Issues (SELINUX or APP ARMOR)
body: From the command line, edit the /etc/sysconfig/selinux file. This file is a symlink to /etc/selinux/config. The configuration file is self-explanatory. Changing the value of SELINUX or SELINUXTYPEchanges the state of SELinux and the name of the policy to be used the next time the system boots.

title: File Write Permissions Issues (SELINUX or APP ARMOR)
body:
[root@host2a ~]# cat /etc/sysconfig/selinux
# This file controls the state of SELinux on the system.
# SELINUX= can take one of these three values:
# enforcing - SELinux security policy is enforced.
# permissive - SELinux prints warnings instead of enforcing.
# disabled - SELinux is fully disabled.
SELINUX=permissive
# SELINUXTYPE= type of policy in use. Possible values are:
# targeted - Only targeted network daemons are protected.
# strict - Full SELinux protection.
SELINUXTYPE=targeted

# SETLOCALDEFS= Check local definition changes
SETLOCALDEFS=0

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: A change was introduced in how events are indexed and stored in version 1149 of the Sysdig platform.

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: Prior to this version, the three types of events were stored in three separate indexes, based on their different sources:

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: Alert events: stored in MySQL (alert_notifications table)

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: Custom events (from both the infrastructure components and any custom event integrations): stored in ElasticSearch (events_v1 index)

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: Policy events (from Sysdig Secure): stored in ElasticSearch (policy_event_v1 index)

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: With version 1149 , they will be combined in one index.

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: The Unified Events migration tool is delivered as a Docker container and is used to migrate events from multiple sources to a single source. When the migration and upgrade are complete, you manually terminate the migration tool.

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: It is highly recommended to run the migration tool BEFORE launching the upgrade to version 1149.

title: v1149+ Migration Tool for Unified Events
body: If you do not migrate before upgrading, you will lose visibility to old custom events in the Sysdig Monitor UI.

title: Prerequisites
body: You must be running Sysdig platform version 1091 . If your on-premises version is less than 1091, upgrade appropriately before running the migration tool.

title: Prerequisites
body: It is highly recommended to follow upgrade best practices:

title: Prerequisites
body: Keep upgrades current

title: Prerequisites
body: Upgrade progressively without skipping versions, and

title: Prerequisites
body: Test upgrades in a non-mission-critical or staging environment before rolling in to production.

title: Prerequisites
body: The migration tool container must have network visibility to the data sources used for re-indexing: MySQL and ElasticSearch.

title: Prerequisites
body: Launch migration before upgrading to version 1149.

title: Where to Find the Tool
body: The migration tool is provided as a containerized JavaApp on a public Quay repository. The Kubernetes and Replicated steps below give the precise location.

title: Running the Migration
body: Since events are constantly being generated, the migration tool executes the migration in batches. After each batch is indexed, the tool will try to fetch the next one, with a predefined cutoff.

title: Running the Migration
body: When the tool finishes indexing old events and has begun to wait for new ones, the Sysdig application upgrade can be launched. In the background, during the upgrade, the tool ensures that incoming events in old indexes are properly reindexed to the new unified table.

title: 1. Run the Container Image (K8s)
body: Run the following command:

title: 1. Run the Container Image (K8s)
body: kubectl -n sysdigcloud create -f MIGRATION_TOOL_SPECS.yaml

title: 1. Run the Container Image (K8s)
body: Where MIGRATION_TOOL_SPECS is defined as follows.

title: 1. Run the Container Image (K8s)
body: (You can obtain the .yaml template from GitHub repository or copy/paste it from this document. )

title: 1. Run the Container Image (K8s)
body:
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
 labels:
 app: sysdigcloud
 role: event-migration
 name: sysdig-event-migration
spec:
 containers:
 - name: event-migration
 image: quay.io/sysdig/onprem_migration:combined-events_0.1.0_1091-1149
 env:
 - name: DB_ENDPOINT
 valueFrom:
 configMapKeyRef:
 name: sysdigcloud-config
 key: mysql.endpoint
 - name: DB_CONNECTION_TIMEOUT
 value: "4000" # Tweak parameter if necessary
 - name: DB_SOCKET_TIMEOUT
 value: "14000" # Tweak parameter if necessary
 - name: DB_USER
 valueFrom:
 configMapKeyRef:
 name: sysdigcloud-config
 key: mysql.user
 - name: DB_PASSWORD
 valueFrom:
 configMapKeyRef:
 name: sysdigcloud-config
 key: mysql.password
 - name: ES_ENDPOINT
 valueFrom:
 configMapKeyRef:
 name: sysdigcloud-config
 key: elasticsearch.url
 - name: ES_PORT
 value: "9200" # Change this param if different
 - name: BATCH_SIZE
 value: "500"
 - name: ALERT_EVENTS
 value: "true"
 - name: CUSTOM_EVENTS
 value: "true"
 - name: POLICY_EVENTS
 value: "true"
 - name: ONPREM
 value: "true"
 - name: REPAIR_MODE
 value: "false"

title: 4. Terminate the Migration Tool (Replicated)

title: 4. Terminate the Migration Tool (Replicated)
body: If necessary, check the Troubleshooting tips, below.

title: Troubleshooting
body: In rare cases, migration errors can occur due to incorrect container configuration, network latency, or temporary cluster overload.

title: Troubleshooting
body: Temporary connection-loss errors in Replicated are expected and are not migration errors, as described in Upgrade the Sysdig Platform (Replicated)

title: Migration Startup Errors
body: Startup errors are normally due to incorrect environment variable settings.

title: Migration Startup Errors
body: Check URL endpoints, passed credentials, flags, etc.

title: Migration Process Errors
body: If you were able to run migration successfully, it functioned for a while, and then began to experience errors, this is most likely caused by network latency or cluster overload. In these cases, the migration tool will try to reduce the pressure on the cluster by reducing batch size exponentially, with a predefined backoff wait time.

title: Migration Process Errors
body: Ultimately, if events cannot be indexed, the migration tool will skip the issued batch and try to index the next batch. Information about the failed batch will be stored in the MySQL table utility_metadata.

title: Temporary Errors
body: If errors are only temporary, simply proceed with Running the Migration Steps.

title: Temporary Errors
body: When migration is complete, run the migration container again with the -e REPAIR_MODE=true parameter. This will index all failed migrations stored in the MySQL table utility_metadata.

title: Continuous Errors
body: At this point, abort the migration attempt. Check the number of errors to decide how to proceed.

title: Continuous Errors
body: To do so, check the MySQL table with:

title: Continuous Errors
body: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM utility_metadata WHERE metadata_id LIKE 'failure-%';

title: LOW Error Count (0 - 1000)
body: Try to identify why errors started (i.e. temporary cluster overload), resolve the problem and re-run the migration.

title: LOW Error Count (0 - 1000)
body: When migration is complete, run the migration container again with the -e REPAIR_MODE=true parameter. This will index all failed migrations stored in the MySQL table utility_metadata.

title: HIGH Error Count (10,000+)
body: Try to identify why errors started (i.e. temporary cluster overload), resolve the problem, and RESET the migration progress completely by clearing all content from the MySQL table utility_metadata.

title: HIGH Error Count (10,000+)
body: (e.g. DELETE FROM utility_metadata;)

title: HIGH Error Count (10,000+)
body: Repeat Running the Migration Steps.

body: All parameters are defined as environment variables.

title: Summary of OpenID Functionality in Sysdig
body: The Sysdig platform ordinarily maintains its own user database to hold a username and password hash. OpenID instead allows for redirection to your organization's IdP to validate username/password and other policies necessary to grant access to Sysdig application(s). Upon successful authentication via OpenID, a corresponding user record in the Sysdig platform’s user database is automatically created, though the password that was sent to the IdP is never seen nor stored by the Sysdig platform.

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Apply the changes:

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: kubectl apply -f ingress.yaml

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Configure Nginx in the Kubernetes API pod.

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Open the configuration file corresponding to the sysdig-api deployment.

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Add the following snippet to the Nginx environment variables section:

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body:
- name: NGINX_NOT_ON_EDGE
 value: "true"

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Apply the changes.

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body: Ensure that the following snippet is added to the Ngnix configuration file at /etc/nginx/conf.d/api.conf:

title: Sysdig Platform Configuration
body:
proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Host $host:$server_port;
proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Server $host;

title: IDP Configuration
body: Ensure that Single Sign On (SSO) configuration is completed on the Sysdig Platform side.

title: IDP Configuration
body: Retrieve the current SSO settings with the API:

title: IDP Configuration
body: curl -v -X GET -H "Accept: application/json" -H "Content-type: application/json" -H 'Authorization: bearer XXXXXX' https://<API ENDPOINT>/api/admin/auth/settings/{{settingsID}}| jq

title: IDP Configuration
body: In the JSON file obtained with the authenticationSettings object , add the following lines:

title: IDP Configuration
body:
"splitDnsSupport": true,
"splitDnsOriginHostHeader": "x-forwarded-server",
"splitDnsOriginSchemeHeader": "x-forwarded-proto"

title: IDP Configuration
body: (optional) If you are using OpenID Connect protocol for SSO, include settings.clientSecret , because it’s not returned with the API call:

title: IDP Configuration
body: "clientSecret": "<Replace with your clientSecret>"

title: IDP Configuration
body: Update the authenticationSettings object with a PUT request to the same endpoint with the changes introduced in the previous steps. For example:

title: IDP Configuration
body:
curl -v -X PUT -H "Accept: application/json" -H "Content-type: application/json" -H 'Authorization: bearer xxxxxxx' https://<API ENDPOINT>/api/admin/auth/settings/1 -d'
{
 "authenticationSettings": {
 "id": 1,
 "version": 5,
 "createdOn": 1577285950000,
 "modifiedOn": 1577350608000,
 "type": "openid",
 "scope": "SYSTEM",
 "settings": {
 "createUserOnLogin": true,
 "forbidPasswordLogin": false,
 "issuer": "https://<Replace with your issuer>.com",
 "clientId": "<Replace with your client_id>",
 "clientSecret": "<Replace with your client_secret>",
 "metadata": null,
 "splitDnsSupport": true,
 "splitDnsOriginHostHeader": "x-forwarded-server",
 "splitDnsOriginSchemeHeader": "x-forwarded-proto",
 "metadataDiscovery": true
 }
 }
}'

title: IDP Configuration
body: Replace <issuer>, <client_id>, and <client_secret> with your own.

title: Disable Password Authentication
body: Sysdig Platform supports disabling password-based authentication on both SaaS and on-prem deployments. As an administrator (super administrator for on-prem), you can use an API to achieve it. This configuration is applicable to those who use single sign-on.

title: SaaS Deployments
body: As an administrator, perform the following:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: Get the Sysdig Platform settings:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: See SaaS Regions and IP Ranges and identify the correct domain URL associated with your Sysdig application and region. For example, for Sysdig Monitor on US East is:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: GET https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/auth/settings/

title: SaaS Deployments
body: For other regions, the format is https://<region>.app.sysdig.com/api/auth/settings. Replace <region> with the region where your Sysidig application is hosted. For example, for Sysdig Monitor in the EU, you use https://eu1.app.sysdig.com/api/auth/settings.

title: SaaS Deployments
body: Find the ID of the active SSO setup:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: GET https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/auth/settings/active

title: SaaS Deployments
body: Retrieve the specific settings associated with the SSO setup:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: GET https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/auth/settings/{id}

title: SaaS Deployments
body: The setting is displayed in a JSON file.

title: SaaS Deployments
body: In the JSON file, change the following from false to true:

title: SaaS Deployments
body: settings/forbidPasswordLogin: True

title: SaaS Deployments
body: Update the setting with a request to the same URL with the same JSON, with the changed parameter. URL depends on the type of deployment.

title: SaaS Deployments
body: PUT https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/auth/settings/{id}

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: As a super administrator, perform the following:

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: Get the Sysdig Platform settings:

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: GET https://<URL-installation>/api/admin/auth/settings

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: Replace <URL-installation> with the URL of your on-prem deployment.

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: Retrieve the specific settings associated with the SSO setup. In a typical scenario, only one IDP exists per deployment.

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: GET https://<URL-installation>/api/auth/settings/{id}

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: The setting is displayed in a JSON file.

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: In the JSON file, change the following from false to true:

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: settings/forbidPasswordLogin: True

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: Update the setting with a request to the same URL with the same JSON, with the changed parameter. URL depends on the type of deployment.

title: On-Prem Deployments
body: PUT https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/admin/auth/settings/{id}

title: Migrating from the ConfigMap Method
body: Previously, the sysdigcloud.restrict.password.login parameter in the Kubernetes ConfigMap has been used to disable password authentication. After installing 3.2.0, deployments utilizing the sysdigcloud.restrict.password.login settings will be automatically migrated to use the new settings.

title: ADFS (SAML)
body: Review SAML (SaaS) before you begin.SAML (SaaS)

title: ADFS (SAML)
body: These instructions assume you already have a working, Internet-accessible ADFS ( Active Directory Federation Service) server. Interoperability testing has been performed specifically with ADFS on Windows Server 2012 R2.

title: ADFS (SAML)
body: Follow the instructions below to configure ADFS with the ADFS Management tool in the Windows Server Manager.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Right-click to Service > Edit Federation Service Properties. Note the hostname in the Federation Service Identifier, as this will be used in the metadata URL that you paste in the Metadata entry on the SAML Configuration page in the Sysdig authentication settings. Specifically, the metadata URL will be of the format https://HOSTNAME/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml. Also, so that the Sysdig platform can access this URL directly, this host must resolve in DNS and have a valid (not self-signed) SSL/TLS certificate.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Add a Relying Party Trust configuration for the Sysdig application.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Right-click to Relying Party Trusts > Add Relying Party Trust and click Start to begin the wizard.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: In the Select Data Source step, click the button to Enter data about the relying party manually, then click Next

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Enter a Display name of your choosing (e.g. "Sysdig Monitor" or "Sysdig Secure"), then click Next

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Click Next to accept the default option to use AD FS profile

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Click Next to skip the selection of an optional token encryption certificate (Sysdig does not support this option)

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Check the box to Enable support for the SAML 2.0 Web SSO protocol, then enter one of the following values for Relying party SAML 2.0 SSO service URL:

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If configuring Sysdig Monitor, enter: https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/saml/auth

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If configuring Sysdig Secure, enter: https://secure.sysdig.com/api/saml/secureAuth

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Then click Next.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: For the Relying party trust identifier, enter one of the following values:

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If configuring Sysdig Monitor, enter: https://app.sysdigcloud.com

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If configuring Sysdig Secure, enter: https://secure.sysdig.com

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Then click Add, then click Next

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Click Next to skip configuration of multi-factor authentication

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Choose a policy for whether users will be permitted to login to the Sysdig application. The default to Permit all users to access the relying party will typically be acceptable. Click Next.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Review the summary and click Next to complete the configuration of the Relying Party Trust

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: The next step will involve adding Claim Rules, so you can leave the box checked to Open the Edit Claim Rules dialog and click the Close button to be brought immediately into the Claim Rules editor

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Ensure that the SamlResponseSignature option matches the Sysdig authentication configuration.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Use the Set-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust/Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust cmdlets via PowerShell to configure SamlResponseSignature .

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body:
-SamlResponseSignature
Specifies the response signatures that the relying party expects. The acceptable values for this parameter are:

AssertionOnly
MessageAndAssertion
MessageOnly

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: For more information, see Set-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Navigate to Settings > Authentication on the Sysdig app and check the Sysdig authentication setting maps to the SamlResponseSignature :

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: For MessageAndAssertion, enable both the options.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Next, use the Claim Rules to ensure that login data is sent as needed to the Sysdig platform. A user's login to the Sysdig platform is based on an email address, and a default ADFS configuration would not send the email address as required. The following configuration ensures the correct field from Active Directory is delivered in the claim.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If not already in the Claim Rules editor from the previous step, navigate to it by right-clicking on the Relying Party Trust that was just created and selecting Edit Claim Rules

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Click Add Rule. At the following screen, accept the default rule template to Send LDAP Attributes as Claims and click Next.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Enter a name for the rule, select Active Directory as the Attribute store, then use the pull-down selectors to pick E-Mail Address as both the LDAP Attribute and Outgoing Claim Type, then similarly make pull-down selections for Given Name and Surname. Once these selections are made, click Finish.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Now click Add Rule again, this time selecting the template for Transform an incoming claim

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Enter a name for the rule, then use the pull-downs to select an Incoming claim type of E-Mail Address, an Outgoing claim type of Name ID, and an Outgoing name ID format of Email, then click Finish.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: (Optional) If you want the user's First Name and Last Name to be included in the records created in the Sysdig platform database when new users successfully login via SAML for the first time, additional Transform rules must also be created. Only the email-based username is strictly required and we already created a rule for this, so this step is optional.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: If you wish to do this, click Add Rule and once again select the template for Transform an incoming claim. Enter a name for the rule, then use the pull-down to select an Incoming claim type of Given Name, and for the Outgoing claim type, directly type first name into the field. After clicking Finish, click Add Rule and create a similar rule to transform the Incoming claim type of Surname to the Outgoing claim type of last name.

title: For Service-Provider-Initiated Login Flow
body: Having clicked Finish after creating your last rule, you will see all rules now in the editor. Click Ok, and your ADFS configuration for your Sysdig application is complete.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: (Optional) The steps above represent a Service-Provider-Initiated SAML configuration. If you would prefer an IdP-initiated SAML configuration, this is also possible with ADFS, but requires the additional steps described below.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: The Sysdig platform requires a specific setting of RelayState in order to accept IdP-initiated login flows. On the ADFS versions tested, we've found this use of RelayState is disabled by default, and a Microsoft article describes the topic in detail. To enable it, as described in a Microsoft forum thread, on your ADFS host, edit %systemroot%\ADFS\Microsoft.IdentityServer.Servicehost.exe.config and add <useRelayStateForIdpInitiatedSignOn enabled="true" /> to the <microsoft.identityserver.web> section. Once the modification is saved, restart ADFS services for the change to take effect.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: You will need to retrieve your Sysdig customer number as described in the Find Your Customer Number article.Find Your Customer Number

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: You will then need to generate an IdP-initiated login URL.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: In addition to having the correct settings, it must be properly URL encoded. To ease this configuration, use this ADFS RelayState Generator tool. When launched, enter the values below, then hit the Generate URL button.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: For the IDP URL String, enter https://YOUR_ADFS_SERVER/adfs/ls/idpinitiatedsignon.aspx

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: For the Relying Party Identifier, enter one of the following values:

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: If configuring Sysdig Monitor, enter https://app.sysdigcloud.com

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: If configuring Sysdig Secure, enter https://secure.sysdig.com

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: For other regions, the format is https://<region>.app.sysdig.com. Replace <region> with the region where your Sysidig application is hosted. For example, for Sysdig Monitor in the EU, you use https://eu1.app.sysdig.com/. See SaaS Regions and IP Ranges for more information.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: For the Relay State/Target App, enter #/&customer=CUSTOMER-ID-NUMBER, substituting the CUSTOMER-ID-NUMBER you retrieved in the previous step

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: This Results URL will be used in the metadata URL that you paste in the Metadata entry in the SAML connection settings .SAML (SaaS)

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: Use the Results URL from the tool to test your IdP-initiated login. Note that per this Microsoft forum thread, it is apparently not possible to configure ADFS to use such a URL when your users select the application from the pull-down menu at https://YOUR_ADFS_SERVER/adfs/ls/idpinitiatedsignon.aspx. However, you may embed the URL into a custom portal or bookmarks list.

title: For IdP-Initiated Login Flow (Optional)
body: Now you can test login using an Active Directory user that has an Email address configured.

title: Test Metadata (Optional)
body: To ensure the metadata URL you copy at the end of the IDP configuration procedure is correct, you can test it by directly accessing it via your browser.

title: Test Metadata (Optional)
body: When accessing the URL, your browser should immediately download an XML file that begins similarly to the example shown below. No entry of credentials or other security measures should be required to successfully download it. If this is not the case, revisit the IDP configuration steps.

title: Azure Active Directory (SAML)
body: This topic explains how to configure SAML Single Sign On (SSO) with Azure Active Directory (AD) and helps you configure Sysdig to allow users to access Sysdig application by using SSO.

title: Prerequisites
body: Administrator privileges on Sysdig and Azure.

title: Configure the Sysdig Application in Azure AD
body: Log in to the Azure AD portal.

title: Configure the Sysdig Application in Azure AD
body: Select Azure Active Directory, then click Enterprise Applications.

title: Configure the Sysdig Application in Azure AD

title: Storage: Configure Options for Capture Files
body: The Sysdig Capture feature allows you to record detailed system trace data via remote connection from any of your agent-installed hosts. In SaaS installations, by default, this data will be stored on Sysdig's secure Amazon S3 storage location, under a separate partition for your account. In on-premises installations, by default, the data will be stored in the Cassandra database.

title: Storage: Configure Options for Capture Files
body: This page describes two custom alternatives: using an AWS S3 bucket (available for SaaS and on-prem) and using custom S3 storage (on-prem only).

title: Configure AWS S3 Storage

title: Configure Custom S3 Endpoint
body: You can set up a custom Amazon-S3-compatible storage, such as Minio or IBM Cloud Object Storage, for storing Captures in a Sysdig on-premises deployment. The capture storage location can be used for both Sysdig Monitor and Sysdig Secure. This is an API-only functionality and currently, no UI support is available.

title: Configure Custom S3 Endpoint
body: You must configure values.yaml corresponding to your Sysdig installation in order for this configuration to work.

body: Your on-premise installation is Installer-based. If you have installed Sysdig Platform manually and you want to configure custom S3 buckets to store your capture files, contact your Sysdig representative.

body: Ensure that the list, get, and put operations are functional on the S3 bucket that you wish to use. Confirm this by using the S3 native tools, for example, as described in AWS CLI for IBM Cloud.

title: Configure Installer
body: Configure the following parameters in the values.yaml file so that collectors, workers, and the API server are aware of the custom endpoint configuration.

title: Configure Installer
body: sysdig.s3.enabled

title: Configure Installer
body:
Required: true
Description: Specifies if storing Sysdig Captures in S3 or S3-compatible storage is enabled or not.
Options:true|false
Default:false

title: Configure Installer
body: For example:

title: Configure Installer
body:
sysdig:
 s3:
 enabled: true

title: Configure Installer
body: sysdig.s3.endpoint

title: Configure Installer
body:
Required: true
Description: The S3 or S3-compatible endpoint for the bucket. This option is ignored if sysdig.s3.enabled is not configured.

title: Configure Installer
body: For example:

title: Configure Installer
body:
sysdig:
 s3:
 endpoint: <your S3-Compatible custom bucket>

title: Configure Installer

title: Configure Installer
body:
Required: true
Description: The name of the S3 or S3-compatible bucket to be used for captures. This option is ignored if sysdig.s3.enabled is not configured

title: Configure Installer
body: For example:

title: Configure Installer
body:
sysdig:
 s3:
 bucketName: <Name of the S3-compatible bucket to be used for captures>

title: Configure Installer
body: sysdig.accessKey

title: Configure Installer
body:
Required: true
Description: The AWS or AWS-compatible access key to be used by Sysdig components to write captures in the S3 bucket.

title: Configure Installer
body: For example:

title: Configure Installer
body:
sysdig:
 accessKey: <AWS-compatible access key>

title: Configure Installer
body: sysdig.secretKey

title: Configure Installer
body:
Required: true
Description: The AWS or AWS-compatible secret key to be used by Sysdig components to write captures in the s3 bucket.

title: Configure Installer
body: For example:

title: Configure Installer
body:
sysdig:
 secretKey: <AWS-compatible secret key>

body: For example, the following AWS CLI command uploads a Sysdig Capture file to a Minio bucket:

title: Configure Installer

body: In this example, the endpoint is http://10.101.140.1:9000/ and the name of the bucket is test.

title: Changing the AWS Services that are Polled
body: When you implement the code and integration steps as described above, it will trigger two types of collection: first the metadata for each service is collected, and then Sysdig will poll for the metrics about the metadata returned. So, if the service is not enabled in your environment, no metadata (and no metrics) are collected about it. If it is enabled, but you do not want to poll metrics, then delete the lines of code related to that service from the IAM policy. This will avoid potential unwanted AWS API requests and potential AWS charges.

title: Working with the Data API
body: The data API provides access to the labels and metrics data captured by Sysdig agents and stored in the Sysdig datastores. Sysdig agents capture process, network, system and other infrastructure data with a 1-second resolution, and sends them to the Sysdig worker service with a 10-second resolution.

title: Working with the Data API
body: The data API allows you to fetch data at the native resolution of 10-second or lower. You can specify the resolution to return data via the sampling parameter. Each resolution has different data retention periods. Since native data capturing is performed with a 1-second resolution, for each metric you need to specify a time aggregation.

title: Working with the Data API
body: Similarly, data associated with individual pods, processes, and so can be aggregated at a higher level. For example, at the host or namespace level. This type of aggregation depends on the list of labels you specify. For instance, you could aggregate data at the host level by specifying a host label. For this to work, you need to specify a group aggregation.

title: Working with the Data API
body: To learn more about data aggregation, see Data Aggregation.

title: General Guidelines for Using the Data API
body: The maximum number of samples you can fetch via the data API is 600. Consequently, the larger the time window for the data retrieval, the lower the resolution will be.

title: General Guidelines for Using the Data API
body: The API enforces a response timeout of 30 seconds. Larger time windows, a higher number of metrics, multiple segments (higher number of columns and rows) might cause a longer response time.

title: General Guidelines for Using the Data API
body: Some labels might not apply to certain entities. When those labels are retrieved, the label value will be null.

title: General Guidelines for Using the Data API
body: Due to a current limitation, the same metric name cannot be specified more than once independent of the aggregations.

title: Sysdig Agent
body: Sysdig agents are simple to deploy and upgrade, and out of the box they will gather and report on a wide variety of pre-defined metrics. Agent installation can be as simple as copy/pasting a few lines of code from a Wizard prompt, or you can follow step-by-step instructions to check supported environments and distributions, review installation options, and customize the agent configuration file post-install.

title: Kernel Header Troubleshooting
body: In addition to the information on Host Requirements for Agent Installation, this page describes how the agent uses kernel headers and tips on troubleshooting, if needed.

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: The Sysdig agent requires a kernel module in order to install successfully on a host. This can be obtained in three ways:

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: Agent compiles the module using kernel headers.

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: If the hosts in your environment already have kernel header files pre-installed, no special action is needed. Or you can install the kernel headers manually; see below.

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: Agent auto-downloads precompiled modules from Sysdig's AWS storage location.

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: If the headers are not already installed but the agent is able to auto-download, no special action is needed. If there is no internet connectivity, you can use method 3 (download from an internal URL).

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: Agent downloads precompiled modules from an internal URL.

title: About Kernel Headers and the Kernel Module
body: Use the environment variable SYSDIG_PROBE_URL. See also Understanding the Agent Config Files. Contact Sysdig support for assistance.

title: To Install Kernel Headers
body: In some cases, the host(s) in your environment may use Unix versions that do not match the provided headers, and the agent may fail to install correctly. In those cases, you must install the kernal headers manually.

title: Debian-Style
body: For Debian-syle distributions, run the command:

title: Debian-Style
body: apt-get -y install linux-headers-$(uname -r)

title: RHEL-Style
body: For RHEL-style distributions, run the command:

title: RHEL-Style
body: yum -y install kernel-devel-$(uname -r)

title: RancherOS
body: For RancherOS distributions, the kernel headers are available in the form of a system service and therefore are enabled using the ros service command:

title: RancherOS
body:
sudo ros service enable kernel-headers-system-docker 
sudo ros service up -d kernel-headers-system-docker

title: RancherOS
body: NOTE: Some cloud hosting service providers supply pre-configured Linux instances with customized kernels. You may need to contact your provider's support desk for instructions on obtaining appropriate header files, or for installing the distribution's default kernel.

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: During an agent installation in an Amazon machine image (AMI) you may encounter the following errors while the installer is trying to compile the Sysdig kernel module:

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: Errors

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: "Unable to find kernel development files for the current kernel version" or

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: "FATAL: Module sysdigcloud-probe not found"

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: This indicates your machine is running a kernel in an older AMI for which the kernel headers are no longer available in the configured repositories. The issue has to do with Amazon purging packages in the yum repository when new Amazon Linux machine images are released.

title: To Correct Kernel Header Errors in AWS AMI
body: The solution is either to update your kernel to a version for which header files are readily available (recommended), or perform a one-time installation of the kernel headers for your older AMI.

title: Option 1: Upgrade Your Host's Kernel
body: First install a new kernel and reboot your instance:

title: Option 1: Upgrade Your Host's Kernel
body:
sudo yum -y install kernel
sudo reboot

title: Option 1: Upgrade Your Host's Kernel
body: After rebooting, check to see if the host is reporting metrics to your Sysdig account. If not, you may need to issue three more commands to install the required header files:

title: Option 1: Upgrade Your Host's Kernel
body:
sudo yum -y install kernel-devel-$(uname -r)
sudo /usr/lib/dkms/dkms_autoinstaller start
sudo service dragent restart

title: Option 2: Install Older Kernel Headers
body: Although it is recommended to upgrade to the latest kernel for security and performance reasons, you can alternatively install the older headers for your AMI.

title: Option 2: Install Older Kernel Headers
body: Find the the AMI version string and install the appropriate headers with the commands:

title: Option 2: Install Older Kernel Headers
body:
releasever=$(cat /etc/os-release | grep 'VERSION_ID' | grep -Eo "[0-9]{4}\.[0-9]{2}")
sudo yum -y --releasever=${releasever} install kernel-devel-$(uname -r)

title: Option 2: Install Older Kernel Headers
body: Issue the remaining commands to allow the Sydig Agent to start successfully:

title: Option 2: Install Older Kernel Headers
body:
sudo /usr/lib/dkms/dkms_autoinstaller start
sudo service dragent restart

title: Agent Install: Kubernetes
body: This document describes how to install a regular Sysdig agent container in a Kubernetes environment. This document assumes you will run the agent container as a Kubernetes pod, which then enables the Sysdig agent automatically to detect and monitor your Kubernetes environment.

title: Agent Install: Kubernetes
body: If you want to install a slim agent, see Install Slim Agent.

title: Agent Install: Kubernetes
body: It is relevant for any platform where Kubernetes is deployed, including Amazon environments (EKS, EC2, ECS), Azure Container Service (AKS), Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), Red Hat OpenShift, and IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service (IKS).

title: Agent Install: Kubernetes
body: You use DaemonSets to deploy agents on every node in your Kubernetes environment. Once deployed, Sysdig Monitor automatically begins monitoring all of your hosts, apps, pods, and services and automatically connects to the Kubernetes API server to pull relevant metadata about the environment. If licensed, Sysdig Secure launches with default policies that you can view and configure to suit your needs. You can access the front-end web interfaces for Sysdig Monitor and Sysdig Secure immediately.

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: Sysdig provides a list of static IP addresses that can be whitelisted in a Sysdig environment, allowing users to establish a network connection to the Sysdig backend without opening complete network connectivity. This is done by setting the Collector IP to collector-static.sysdigcloud.com.

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: The sysdig-agent-configmap.yaml file can be edited either locally or using the edit command in Kubernetes. refer to the section above for more information.

body: Uncomment the following lines:

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: collector:

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: collector_port

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: Set the collector: value to collector-static.sysdigcloud.com

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: See SaaS Regions and IP Ranges and identify the correct URL associated with your Sysdig collector and region.

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: Set the collector_port: value to 6443

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: Save the file.

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body: The example file below shows how the sysdig-agent-configmap.yaml file should look after configuration:

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)
body:
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
 name: sysdig-agent
data:
 dragent.yaml: |
 ### Agent tags
 # tags: linux:ubuntu,dept:dev,local:nyc

 #### Sysdig Software related config ####

 # Sysdig collector address
 collector: collector-static.sysdigcloud.com

 # Collector TCP port
 collector_port: 6443

 # Whether collector accepts ssl/TLS
 ssl: true

 # collector certificate validation
 ssl_verify_certificate: true

 # Sysdig Secure
 security:
 enabled: true

 #######################################
 # new_k8s: true
 # k8s_cluster_name: production

title: Steps for GKE
body: Note that the standard Sysdig agent cannot be installed on GKE COS because Sysdig relies on a kernel module that COS does not allow. To accommodate this limitation Sysdig has developed an alternate probe built on eBPF, a "universal in-kernel virtual machine."

title: Kernel Headers
body: The Sysdig agent requires kernel header files to install successfully on a host.

title: Kernel Headers
body: This setup step is required for some environments and not others, as noted.

title: Kernel Headers
body: If the hosts in your environment match the pre-compiled kernel modules available from Sysdig, no special action is required.

title: Kernel Headers

title: Kernel Headers

title: Configure for OpenShift
body: If you are using Red Hat OpenShift, these steps are required. They describe how to create a project, assign and label the node selector, create a privileged service account, and add it to a cluster role.

title: Copy/Paste Sample Code Block
body: In the example code, this document uses sysdig-agent for the PROJECT NAME (-n), the SERVICE ACCOUNT (-z), and the NODE SELECTOR.

title: Copy/Paste Sample Code Block
body: You can copy-paste the code as-is, or follow the steps below to customize your naming conventions.

oc adm new-project sysdig-agent --node-selector='app=sysdig-agent'
oc label node --all "app=sysdig-agent"
oc project sysdig-agent
oc create serviceaccount sysdig-agent
oc adm policy add-scc-to-user privileged -n sysdig-agent -z sysdig-agent

title: Docker Container Agent Installation
body: The Sysdig agent can be deployed as a Docker container.

title: Docker Container Agent Installation
body: The commands below can also be copy/pasted from the Welcome Wizard or the Agent Installation page in the Sysdig UI.Agent Installation: Overview and Key

title: Docker Container Agent Installation
body: In that case, your access key will already be included in the command automatically.

title: SaaS
body: Run the agent image, providing the access key and (optional) user-defined tags:

title: SaaS
body:
docker run -d --name sysdig-agent \
--restart always \
--privileged \
--net host \
--pid host\
 -e ACCESS_KEY=[ACCESS_KEY] \
 -e COLLECTOR=[COLLECTOR_ADDRESS] \
-e TAGS=[TAGS] \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock \
-v /dev:/host/dev \
-v /proc:/host/proc:ro \
-v /boot:/host/boot:ro \
-v /lib/modules:/host/lib/modules:ro \
-v /usr:/host/usr:ro --shm-size=512m sysdig/agent

title: SaaS
body: For the COLLECTOR, find the address for your region..

title: On-Premises
body: Provide collector and SSL/TLS information in addition to access key and optional tags:

title: On-Premises
body:
docker run -d --name sysdig-agent \
--restart always \
--privileged \
--net host \
--pid host \
-e ACCESS_KEY=[ACCESS_KEY] \
-e COLLECTOR=[COLLECTOR_ADDRESS] \
-e SECURE=true \
-e CHECK_CERTIFICATE=true \
[-e TAGS=[TAGS]] 
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock \
-v /dev:/host/dev \
-v /proc:/host/proc:ro \
-v /boot:/host/boot:ro \
-v /lib/modules:/host/lib/modules:ro \
-v /usr:/host/usr:ro --shm-size=512m sysdig/agent

title: On-Premises
body: CHECK_CERTIFICATE should be set to false if a self-signed certificate or private, CA-signed cert is used.

title: Service Agent Installation on Linux Host
body: Use these instructions to install the agent on the host itself, not in a container. Install on each host in the environment.

title: Service Agent Installation on Linux Host
body: The command lines below can also be copy/pasted from the Welcome wizard or the Settings>Agent Installation page in the Sysdig Monitor interface.

title: Service Agent Installation on Linux Host
body: In that case, your access key will already be included in the command automatically.

title: SaaS
body: Run the following command:

title: SaaS
body: curl -s https://download.sysdig.com/stable/install-agent | sudo bash -s -- --access_key [ACCESS_KEY] --collector [COLLECTOR_ADDRESS] [--tags [TAGS]]

title: SaaS
body: Where [ACCESS_KEY] is your unique agent access key string. For example, 1234-your-key-here-1234. [TAGS] is an optional list of user-defined agent tags. For example, role:webserver,location:europe.

title: SaaS
body: Find the collector endpoint for your region listed here.

title: SaaS
body: Make sure restarting the agent results in starting the service:

title: SaaS
body: sudo systemctl enable dragent

title: On-Premises
body: Run the following command:

title: On-Premises
body: curl -s https://download.sysdig.com/stable/install-agent | sudo bash -s -- --access_key [ACCESS_KEY] --collector [COLLECTOR_ADDRESS] --secure true --check_certificate true [--tags [TAGS]]

title: On-Premises
body: check_certificate should be set to false if a self-signed certificate, a private, or a CA-signed certificate is used. See information about SSL in on-premises here.

title: On-Premises
body: Make sure restarting the agent results in starting the service:

title: On-Premises
body: sudo systemctl enable dragent

title: Connect to the Sysdig Backend via Static IPs (SaaS only)

user@host:~$ docker run --name sysdig-agent \
--privileged \
--net host \
--pid host \
-e ACCESS_KEY=[ACCESS_KEY] \
-e TAGS=[TAGS] \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock \
-v /dev:/host/dev \
-v /proc:/host/proc:ro \
-v /boot:/host/boot:ro \
-v /lib/modules:/host/lib/modules:ro \
-v /usr:/host/usr:ro \
-e COLLECTOR=collector-static.sysdigcloud.com \
-e COLLECTOR_PORT=6443 \
-e SECURE=true \
-e CHECK_CERTIFICATE=true \
--shm-size=512m \
sysdig/agent

body: The slim agent is a lighter version of the Sysdig agent that is created by splitting the regular agent image into two components responsible for different functions. The slim agent reduces the surface area of attack for potential vulnerabilities and is, therefore, more secure.

title: Install Slim Agent
body: You install the slim agent package as two separate containers:

title: Install Slim Agent
body: agent-kmodule: Responsible for downloading and building the kernel module. The image is short-lived. The container exits after the kernel module is loaded. The transient nature of the container reduces the time and opportunities for exploiting any potential vulnerabilities present in the container image.

title: Install Slim Agent
body: Prerequisites: The package depends on Dynamic Kernel Module Support (DKMS) and requires the compiler and kernel headers installed if you are using the agent-kmodule to build the kernel probe. Alternatively, you can use it without the kernel headers. In such cases, the agent-kmodule will attempt to download a pre-built kernel probe if it is present in the Sysdig probe repository.

title: Install Slim Agent
body: The module contains:

title: Install Slim Agent
body: The driver sources

title: Install Slim Agent
body: A post-install script that builds the module upon installation

title: Install Slim Agent
body: agent-slim: Responsible for running the agent module once the kernel module has been loaded. When the slim agent is up and running it functions the same way as the regular agent.

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: The agent is installed by running sysdig/agent-kmodule first, followed by running sysdig/agent-slim.

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: Every host restart requires subsequent running of agent-kmodule and agent-slim containers.

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: Build and load the kernel module:

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: docker run -it --privileged --rm --name sysdig-agent-kmodule -v /usr:/host/usr:ro -v /boot:/host/boot:ro -v /lib/modules:/host/lib/modules:ro sysdig/agent-kmodule

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: Run the agent module:

title: Install Slim Agent in a Non-Orchestrated Environment
body: docker run -it --rm --name sysdig-agent --privileged --net host --pid host -e ACCESS_KEY=YOUR-ACCESS-KEY -v /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock -v /dev:/host/dev -v /proc:/host/ sysdig/agent-slim

title: Install Slim Agent on Kubernetes
body: The agent is installed by scheduling both the agent-kmodule and agent-slim containers into a single daemonset. The agent-kmodule container is defined as an init container, which ensures that it runs first and must succeed in order for the other containers to run.

title: Install Slim Agent on Kubernetes
body: The slim agent is not supported on GKE clusters running on COS (Container Optimized OS).

title: Disconnecting Agents
body: If agents are disconnecting, there could be problems with addresses that need to be resolved in the agent configuration files. See also Understanding the Agent Config Files.

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: The Sysdig agent will use the eth0 MAC address to identify the different hosts within an infrastructure. In a virtualized environment, you should confirm each of your VM's eth0 MAC addresses are unique.

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: If a unique address cannot be configured, you can supply an additional parameter in the Sysdig agent's dragent.yaml configuration file: machine_id_prefix: prefix

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: The prefix text can be any string and will be prepended to the MAC address as reported in the Sysdig Monitor web interface's Explore tables.

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: Example: (using ADDITIONAL_CONF rather than Kubernetes Configmap)

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: Here is an example Docker run command installing the parameter via the ADDITIONAL_CONF parameter

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: docker run --name sysdig-agent --privileged --net host --pid host -e ACCESS_KEY=abc123-1234-abcd-4321-abc123def456 -e TAGS=tag1:value1 -e ADDITIONAL_CONF="machine_id_prefix: MyPrefix123-" -v /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock -v /dev:/host/dev -v /proc:/host/proc:ro -v /boot:/host/boot:ro -v /lib/modules:/host/lib/modules:ro -v /usr:/host/usr:ro sysdig/agent

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: The resulting /opt/draios/etc/dragent.yaml config file would look like this:

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body:
customerid:abc123-1234-abcd-4321-abc123def456
tags: tag1:value1
machine_id_prefix: MyPrefix123-

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: You will then see all of your hosts, provided that all the prefixes are unique. The prefix will be visible whenever the MAC address is displayed in any view.

title: Check for Duplicate MAC addresses
body: See also: Agent Configuration.

title: Check for Conflicting MAC addresses in GKE environments
body: In Google Container Engine (GKE) environments, MAC addresses could be repeated across multiple hosts. This would cause some hosts running Sysdig agents not to appear in your web interface.

title: Check for Conflicting MAC addresses in GKE environments
body: To address this, add a unique machine ID prefix to each config you use to deploy the agent to a given cluster (i.e. each sysdig-daemonset.yaml file).

title: Check for Conflicting MAC addresses in GKE environments
body: Note: This example uses the (v1) ADDITIONAL_CONF, rather than (v2) Configmap method.

title: Check for Conflicting MAC addresses in GKE environments
body: - name: ADDITIONAL_CONF value: "machine_id_prefix: mycluster1-prefix-"

title: Can't See Metrics After Agent Install
body: If agents were successfully installed, you could log in to the Sysdig Monitor UI, but no metrics are displayed in the Explore panel, first confirm that the agent license count has not been exceeded. Then check for any proxy, firewall, or host security policies preventing proper agent communication to the Sysdig Monitor backend infrastructure.

title: Check License Count
body: If network connectivity is good, the agent will connect to the backend but will be disconnected after a few seconds if the license count has been exceeded.

title: Check License Count

title: Check License Count
body: See Subscription: Change Number of Licensed Agents for details.

body: Check Network Policy

body: Check your service provider VPC security groups to verify that network ACLs are set to allow the agent's outbound traffic over TCP port 6443.

title: Outbound IP Addresses
body: Due to the distributed nature of the Sysdig Monitor infrastructure, the agent must be open for outbound connections to collector.sysdigcloud.com on all outbound IP addresses.
