 - ErrImageNeverPull # Ctr Img NeverPull Policy Violate (warning)*
 - BackOff # Back Off Ctr Start, Image Pull (warning)
 - Created # Container Created (information)
 - Started # Container Started (information)
 - Killing # Killing Container (information)*
 - Unhealthy # Container Unhealthy (warning)
 - FailedSync # Pod Sync Failed (warning)
 - FailedValidation # Failed Pod Config Validation (warning)
 - OutOfDisk # Out of Disk (information)*
 - HostPortConflict # Host/Port Conflict (warning)*
 replicationController:
 - SuccessfulCreate # Pod Created (information)*
 - FailedCreate # Pod Create Failed (warning)*
 - SuccessfulDelete # Pod Deleted (information)*
 - FailedDelete # Pod Delete Failed (warning)*

title: Enable/Disable Events Collection with events Parameter
body: To customize the default events collected for a specific application (by either enabling or disabling events), add an events entry to dragent.yaml as described in the examples below.

title: Enable/Disable Events Collection with events Parameter
body: An entry in a section in dragent.yaml overrides the entire section in the default configuration.

title: Enable/Disable Events Collection with events Parameter
body: For example, the Pulling entry below will permit only kubernetes pod Pulling events to be collected and all other kubernetes pod events settings in dragent.default.yaml will be ignored.

title: Enable/Disable Events Collection with events Parameter
body: However, other kubernetes sections - node and replicationController- remain intact and will be used as specified in dragent.default.yaml.

title: Example 1: Collect Only Certain Events
body: Collect only 'Pulling' events from Kubernetes for pods:

title: Example 1: Collect Only Certain Events
body:
events:
 kubernetes:
 pod:
 - Pulling

title: Example 2: Disable All Events in a Section
body: To disable all events in a section, set the event section to none:

title: Example 2: Disable All Events in a Section
body:
events:
 kubernetes: none
 docker: none

title: Example 3: Combine Methods
body: These methods can be combined. For example, disable all kubernetes node and docker image events and limit docker container events to [attach, commit, copy] (components events in other sections will be collected as specified by default):

title: Example 3: Combine Methods
body:
events:
 kubernetes:
 node: none
 docker:
 image: none
 container:
 - attach
 - commit
 - copy

title: Note: Format Sequences as List or Single Line
body: In addition to bulleted lists, sequences can also be specified in a bracketed single line, eg.:

title: Note: Format Sequences as List or Single Line
body:
events:
 kubernetes:
 pod: [Pulling, Pulled, Failed]

title: Note: Format Sequences as List or Single Line
body: So, the following two settings are equivalent, permitting only Pulling, Pulled, Failed events for pods to be emitted:

title: Note: Format Sequences as List or Single Line
body:
events:
 kubernetes:
 pod: [Pulling, Pulled, Failed]

title: Note: Format Sequences as List or Single Line
body:
events:
 kubernetes:
 pod:
 - Pulling
 - Pulled
 - Failed

title: Change Event Collection by Severity with log Parameter
body: Events are limited globally at the agent level based on severity, using the log settings in dragent.yaml.

title: Change Event Collection by Severity with log Parameter
body: The default setting for the events severity filter is information (only warning and higher severity events are transmitted).

title: Change Event Collection by Severity with log Parameter
body: Valid severity levels are: none, emergency, alert, critical, error, warning, notice, information, debug.

title: Example 1: Block Low-Severity Messages
body: Block all low-severity messages (notice, information, debug):

title: Example 1: Block Low-Severity Messages
body:
log:
 event_priority: warning

title: Example 2: Block All Event Collection
body: Block all event collection:

title: Example 2: Block All Event Collection
body:
log:
 event_priority: none

title: Example 2: Block All Event Collection
body: For other uses of the log settings see Optional: Change the Agent Log Level.

title: Include/Exclude Custom Metrics
body: For more information, see Integrate Applications (Default App Checks).Integrate Applications (Default App Checks)

title: Include/Exclude Custom Metrics
body: It is possible to filter custom metrics in the following ways:

title: Include/Exclude Custom Metrics
body: Ability to include/exclude custom metrics using configurable patterns,

title: Include/Exclude Custom Metrics
body: Ability to log which custom metrics are exceeding limits

title: Include/Exclude Custom Metrics
body: After you identify those key custom metrics that must be received, use the new 'include' and 'exclude' filtering parameters to make sure you receive them before the metrics limit is hit.

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: Here is an example configuration entry that would be put into the agent config file: (/opt/draios/etc/dragent.yaml)

title: Filter Metrics Example
body:
metrics_filter:
 - include: test.*
 - exclude: test.*
 - include: haproxy.backend.*
 - exclude: haproxy.*
 - exclude: redis.*

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: Given the config entry above, this is the action for these metrics:

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: test.* → send

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: haproxy.backend.request → send

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: haproxy.frontend.bytes → drop

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: redis.keys → drop

title: Filter Metrics Example
body: The semantic is: whenever the agent is reading metrics, they are filtered according to configured filters and the filtering rule order - the first rule that matches will be applied. Thus since the inclusion item for test.* was listed first it will be followed and that second 'exclude' rule for the same exact metric entry will be ignored.

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: Logging is disabled by default. You can enable logging to see which metrics are accepted or dropped by adding the following configuration entry into the dragent.yaml config file:

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: metrics_excess_log: true

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: When logging of excess metrics is enabled, logging occurs at INFO-level, every 30 seconds and lasts for 10 seconds. The entries that can be seen in /opt/draios/logs/draios.log will be formatted like this:

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: +/-[type] [metric included/excluded]: metric.name (filter: +/-[metric.filter])

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: The first '+' or '-', followed by 'type' provides an easy way to quickly scan the list of metrics and spot which are included or excluded ('+' means "included", '-' means "excluded").

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: The second entry specifies metric type ("statsd", "app_check", "service_check", or "jmx").

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: A third entry spells out whether "included" or "excluded", followed by the metric name. Finally, inside the last entry (in parentheses), there is information about filter applied and its effect ('+' or '-', meaning "include" or "exclude").

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: With this example filter rule set:

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body:
metrics_filter:
 - include: mongo.statsd.net*
 - exclude: mongo.statsd.*

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body: We might see the following INFO-level log entries (timestamps stripped):

title: Logging Accepted/Dropped Metrics
body:
-[statsd] metric excluded: mongo.statsd.vsize (filter: -[mongo.statsd.*])
+[statsd] metric included: mongo.statsd.netIn (filter: +[mongo.statsd.net*])

title: Prioritize/Include/Exclude Designated Containers
body: To get the most out of Sysdig Monitor, you may want to customize the way in which container data is prioritized and reported. Use this page to understand the default behavior and sorting rules, and to implement custom behavior when and where you need it. This can help reduce agent and backend load by not monitoring unnecessary containers, or-- if encountering backend limits for containers-- you can filter to ensure that the important containers are always reported.

title: Overview
body: By default, a Sysdig agent will collect metrics from all containers it detects in an environment. When reporting to the Monitor interface, it uses default sorting behavior to prioritize what container information to display first.

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: Out of the box, it chooses the containers with the highest

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: CPU

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: Memory

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: File IO

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: Net IO

title: Understand Default Behavior
body: and allocates approximately 1/4 of the total limit to each stat type.

title: Understand Simple Container Filtering
body: As of agent version 0.86, it is possible set a use_container_filter parameter in the agent config file, tag/label specific containers, and set include/exclude rules to push those containers to the top of the reporting hierarchy.

title: Understand Simple Container Filtering
body: This is an effective sorting tool when:

title: Understand Simple Container Filtering
body: You can manually mark each container with an include or exclude tag, AND

title: Understand Simple Container Filtering
body: The number of includes is small (say, less than 100)

title: Understand Simple Container Filtering
body: In this case, the containers that explicitly match the include rules will take top priority.

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: In some enterprises, the number of containers is too high to tag with simple filtering rules, and/or the include_all group is too large to ensure that the most-desired containers are consistently reported. As of Sysdig agent version 0.91, you can append another parameter to the agent config file, smart_container_reporting.

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: This is an effective sorting tool when:

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: The number of containers is large and you can't or won't mark each one with include/exclude tags, AND

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: There are certain containers you would like to always prioritize

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: This helps ensure that even when there are thousands of containers in an environment, the most-desired containers are consistently reported.

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: Container filtering and smart container reporting affect the monitoring of all the processes/metrics within a container, including StatsD, JMX, app-checks, and built-in metrics.

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: Prometheus metrics are attached to processes, rather than containers, and are therefore handled differently.

title: Understand Smart Container Reporting
body: The container limit is set in dragent.yaml under containers:limit:

title: Understand Sysdig Aggregated Container
body: The sydig_aggregated parameter is automatically activated when smart container reporting is enabled, to capture the most-desired metrics from the containers that were excluded by smart filtering and report them under a single entity. It appears like any other container in the Sysdig Monitor UI, with the name "sysdig_aggregated."

title: Understand Sysdig Aggregated Container
body: Sysdig_aggregated can report on a wide array of metrics; see Sysdig_aggregated Container Metrics. However, because this is not a regular container, certain limitations apply:Sysdig_aggregated Container Metrics

title: Understand Sysdig Aggregated Container
body: container_id and container_image do not exist.

title: Understand Sysdig Aggregated Container
body: The aggregated container cannot be segmented by certain metrics that are excluded, such as process.

title: Understand Sysdig Aggregated Container
body: Some default dashboards associated with the aggregated container may have some empty graphs.

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: By default, the filtering feature is turned off. It can be enabled by adding the following line to the agent configuration:

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: use_container_filter: true

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: When enabled, the agent will follow include/exclude filtering rules based on:

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: container image

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: container name

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: container label

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: Kubernetes annotation or label

title: Use Simple Container Filtering
body: The default behavior in default.dragent.yaml excludes based on a container label (com.sysdig.report) and/or a Kubernetes pod annotation (.sysdig.com/report ).

title: Container Condition Parameters and Rules
body: Container Condition Parameters and Rules

title: Parameters
body: The condition parameters are described in the following table:

title: Rules
body: Once enabled (when use_container_filter: true is set), the agent will follow filtering rules from the container_filter section.

title: Rules
body: Each rule is an include or exclude rule which can contain one or more conditions.

title: Rules
body: The first matching rule in the list will determine if the container is included or excluded.

title: Rules
body: The conditions consist of a key name and a value. If the given key for a container matches the value, the rule will be matched.

title: Rules
body: If a rule contains multiple conditions they all need to match for the rule to be considered a match.

title: Default Configuraton
body: The dragent.default.yaml contains the following default configuration for container filters:

title: Default Configuraton
body:
use_container_filter: false

container_filter:
 - include:
 container.label.com.sysdig.report: true
 - exclude:
 container.label.com.sysdig.report: false
 - include:
 kubernetes.pod.annotation.sysdig.com/report: true
 - exclude:
 kubernetes.pod.annotation.sysdig.com/report: false
 - include:
 all

title: Default Configuraton
body: Note that it excludes via a container.label and by a kubernetes.pod.annotation.

title: Default Configuraton
body: The examples on this page show how to edit in the dragent.yaml file directly. Convert the examples to Docker or Helm commands, if applicable for your situation.

title: Enable Container Filtering in the Agent Config File
body: Enable Container Filtering in the Agent Config File

title: Option 1: Use the Default Configuration
body: To enable container filtering using the default configuration in default.dragent.yaml (above), follow the steps below.

title: 1. Apply Labels and/or Annotations to Designated Containers
body: To set up, decide which containers should be excluded from automatic monitoring.

title: 1. Apply Labels and/or Annotations to Designated Containers
body: Apply the container label .com.sysdig.report and/or the Kubernetes pod annotation sysdig.com/report to the designated containers.

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: Add the following line to dragent.yaml to turn on the default functionality:

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: use_container_filter: true

title: Option 2: Define Your Own Rules
body: You can also edit dragent.yaml to apply your own container filtering rules.

title: 1. Designate Containers
body: To set up, decide which containers should be excluded from automatic monitoring.

title: 1. Designate Containers
body: Note the image, name, label, or Kubernetes pod information as appropriate, and build your rule set accordingly.

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: For example:

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body:
use_container_filter: true

container_filter:
 - include:
 container.name: my-app
 - include:
 container.label.com.sysdig.report: true
 - exclude:
 kubernetes.namespace.name: kube-system
 container.image: "gcr.io*"
 - include:
 all

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: The above example shows a container_filter with 3 include rules and 1 exclude rule.

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: If the container name is "my-app" it will be included.

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: Likewise, if the container has a label with the key "com.sysdig.report" and with the value "true".

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: If neither of those rules is true, and the container is part of a Kubernetes hierarchy within the "kube-system" namespace and the container image starts with " gcr.io ", it will be excluded.

title: 2. Edit the Agent Configuration
body: The last rule includes all, so any containers not matching an earlier rule will be monitored and metrics for them will be sent to the backend.

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: As of Sysdig agent version 0.91, you can add another parameter to the config file: smart_container_reporting = true

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: This enables several new prioritization checks:

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: container_filter (you would enable and set include/exclude rules, as described above)

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: container age

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: high stats

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: legacy patterns

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: The sort is modified with the following rules in priority order:

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: User-specified containers come before others

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: Containers reported previously should be reported before those which have never been reported

title: Use Smart Container Reporting
body: Containers with higher usage by each of the 4 default stats should come before those with lower usage

title: Enable Smart Container Reporting and sysdig_aggregated
body: Set up any simple container filtering rules you need, following either Option 1 or Option 2, above.

title: Enable Smart Container Reporting and sysdig_aggregated
body: Edit the agent configuration:

title: Enable Smart Container Reporting and sysdig_aggregated
body: smart_container_reporting: true

title: Enable Smart Container Reporting and sysdig_aggregated
body: This turns on both smart_container_reporting and sysdig_aggregated. The changes will be visible in the Sysdig Monitor UI.

title: Enable Smart Container Reporting and sysdig_aggregated
body: See also Sysdig_aggregated Container Metrics..Sysdig_aggregated Container Metrics

body: When the log level is set to DEBUG, the following messages may be found in the logs:

title: Include/Exclude Processes
body: In addition to filtering data by container, it is also possible to filter independently by process. Broadly speaking, this refinement helps ensure that relevant data is reported while noise is reduced. More specifically, use cases for process filtering may include:

title: Include/Exclude Processes
body: Wanting to alert reliably whenever a given process goes down.  The total number of processes can exceed the reporting limit; when that happens, some processes are not reported. In this case, an unreported process could be misinterpreted as being "down." Specify a filter for 30-40 processes to guarantee that they will always be reported.

title: Include/Exclude Processes
body: Wanting to limit the number of noisy but inessential processes being reported, for example: sed, awk, grep, and similar tools that may be used infrequently.

title: Include/Exclude Processes
body: Wanting to prioritize workload-specific processes, perhaps from integrated applications such as NGINX, Supervisord or PHP-FPM.

title: Include/Exclude Processes
body: Note that you can report on processes and containers independently; the including/excluding of one does not affect the including/excluding of the other.

title: Prerequisites_Processes
body: This feature requires the following Sysdig  component versions:

title: Prerequisites_Processes
body: Sysdig agent version 0.91 or higher

title: Prerequisites_Processes
body: For on-premises installations: version 3.2.0.2540 or higher

title: Understand Process Filtering Behavior
body: By default, processes are reported according to internal criteria such as resource usage (CPU/memory/file and net IO) and container count.

title: Understand Process Filtering Behavior
body: If you choose to enable process filtering, processes in the include list will be given preference over other internal criteria.

title: Understand Process Filtering Behavior
body: Processes are filtered based on a standard priority filter description already used in Sysdig yaml files. It is comprised of -include and -exclude statements which are matched in order, with evaluation ceasing with the first matched statement. Statements are considered matched if EACH of the conditions in the statement is met.

title: Use Process Filtering
body: Edit dragent.yaml per the following patterns to implement the filtering you need.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: The process: condition parameters and rules are described below.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: The process: Condition Parameters

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: Rules

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: container.image: my_container_image  Validates whether the container image associated with the process is a wild card match of the provided image name

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: container.name: my_container_name  Validates whether the container name associated with the process is a wild card match of the provided image name

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: container.label.XYZ: value  Validates whether the label XYZ of the container associated with the process is a wildcard match of the provided value

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: process.name: my_process_name  Validates whether the name of the process is a wild card match of the provided value

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: process.cmdline: value  Checks whether the executable name of a process contains the specified value, or any argument to the process is a wildcard match of the provided value

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: appcheck.match: value  Checks whether the process has any appcheck which is a wildcard match of the given value

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: all  Matches all processes, but does not whitelist them, nor does it blacklist them. If no filter is provided, the default is -include all. However, if a filter is provided and no match is made otherwise, then all unmatched processes will be blacklisted. In most cases, the definition of a process filter should end with -include: all.

title: Examples
body: Examples

title: Block All Processes from a Container
body: Block all processes from a given container. No processes from some_container_name will be reported.

title: Block All Processes from a Container
body:
process:
 flush_filter_enabled: true
  flush_filter:
 - exclude:
 container.name: some_container_name
 - include:
 allprocess:   flush_filter: - exclude: container.name: some_container_name - include: all

title: Prioritize Processes from a Container
body: Send all processes from a given container at high priority.

title: Prioritize Processes from a Container
body:
process:
 flush_filter_enabled: true
 flush_filter:
 - include:
 container.name: some_container_name
 - include:
 all

title: Prioritize "java" Processes
body: Send all processes that contain 'java" in the name at high priority.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes
body:
process:
 flush_filter_enabled: true
 flush_filter:
 - include:
 process.name: java 
 - include:
 all

title: Prioritize "java" Processes from a Particular Container
body: Send processes containing "java" from a given container at high priority.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes from a Particular Container
body:
process:
 flush_filter_enabled: true
 flush_filter:
 - include:
 container.name: some_container_name
 process.name: java
 - include:
 all

title: Prioritize "java" Processes not in a Particular Container
body: Send all processes that contain "java" in the name that are not in container some_container_nane.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes not in a Particular Container
body:
process:
 flush_filter_enabled: true
 flush_filter:
 - exclude:
 container.name: some_container_name
 - include:
 process.name: java
 - include:
 all

title: Prioritize "java" Processes even from an Excluded Container
body: Send all processes containing "java" in the name. If a process does not contain "java" in the name and if the container within which the process runs is named  some_container_name,  then exclude it.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes even from an Excluded Container
body: Note that each include/exclude rule is handled sequentially and hierarchically so that even if the container is excluded, it can still report "java" processes.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes even from an Excluded Container
body:
flush_filter:
 - flush_filter_enabled: true
 - include:
 process.name: java
 - exclude:
 container.name: some_container_name
 - include:
 all

title: Prioritize "java" Processes and "sql" Processes from Different Containers
body: Send Java processes from one container and SQL processes from another at high priority.

title: Prioritize "java" Processes and "sql" Processes from Different Containers
body:
process:
 flush_filter:
 - flush_filter_enabled: true
 - include:
 container.name: java_container_name
 process.name: java
 - include
 container.name: sql_container_name
 process.name: sql
 - include
 all

title: Report ONLY Processes in a Particular Container
body: Only send processes running in a container with a given label.

title: Report ONLY Processes in a Particular Container
body:
process:
 flush_filter:
 - flush_filter_enabled: true
 - include:
 =container.label.report_processes_from_this_container_example_label: true
 - exclude:
 all

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Agent modes provide the ability to control metric collection to fit your scale and specific requirement. You can choose one of the following modes to do so:

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Monitor

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Monitor Light

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Troubleshooting

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Essentials

title: Configure Sysdig Monitor Using Agent Modes
body: Using a stripped-down mode limits collection of unneeded metrics, which in turn prevents the consumption of excess resources and helps reduce expenses.

title: Monitor
body: The Monitor mode offers an extensive collection of metrics. We recommend this mode to monitor enterprise environments.

title: Monitor
body: monitor is the default mode if you are running the Enterprise tier. To switch back to the Monitor mode from a different mode, do one of the following:

title: Monitor
body: Add the following to the dragent.yaml file and restart the agent:

title: Monitor

feature:

title: Monitor
body: Remove the parameter related to the existing mode from the dragent.yaml file and restart the agent. For example, to switch from troubleshooting mode to monitor, delete the following lines:

title: Monitor
body:
feature: 
 mode: troubleshooting

title: Monitor Light

title: Enable HTTP Proxy for Agents
body: You can configure the agent to allow it to communicate with the Sysdig collector through an HTTP proxy. HTTP proxy is usually configured to offer greater visibility and better management of the network.

title: Agent Behaviour
body: The agent can connect to the collector through an HTTP proxy by sending an HTTP CONNECT message and receiving a response. The proxy then initiates a TCP connection to the collector. These two connections form a tunnel that acts like one logical connection.

title: Agent Behaviour
body: By default, the agent will encrypt all messages sent through this tunnel. This means that after the initial CONNECT message and response, all the communication on that tunnel is encrypted by SSL end-to-end. This encryption is controlled by the top-level ssl parameter in the agent configuration.

title: Agent Behaviour
body: Optionally, the agent can add a second layer of encryption, securing the CONNECT message and response. This second layer of encryption may be desired in the case of HTTP authentication if there is a concern that network packet sniffing could be used to determine the user's credentials. This second layer of encryption is enabled by setting the ssl parameter to true in the http_proxy section of the agent configuration. See Examples for details.

title: Configuration
body: You specify the following parameters at the same level as http_proxy in the dragent.yaml file. These existing configuration options affect the communication between the agent and collector (both with and without a proxy.

title: Configuration
body: ssl: If set to true, the metrics sent from the agent to the collector are encrypted.

title: Configuration
body: ssl_verify_certificate: Determines whether the agent verifies the SSL certificate sent from the collector.

title: Configuration
body: The following configuration options affect the behavior of the HTTP Proxy setting. You specify them under the http_proxy heading in the dragent.yaml file.

title: Configuration
body: proxy_host: Indicates the hostname of the proxy server. The default is an empty string, which implies communication through an HTTP proxy is disabled.

title: Configuration
body: proxy_port: Specifies the port on the proxy server the agent should connect to. The default is 0, which indicates that the HTTP proxy is disabled.

title: Configuration
body: proxy_user : Required if HTTP authentication is configured. This option specifies the username for the HTTP authentication. The default is an empty string, which indicates that authentication is not configured.

title: Configuration
body: proxy_password : Required if HTTP authentication is configured. This option specifies the password for the HTTP authentication. The default is an empty string. Specifying proxy_user with no proxy_password is allowed.

title: Configuration
body: ssl: If set to true, the connection between the agent and the proxy server is encrypted.

title: Configuration
body: Note that this parameter requires the top-level ssl parameter to be enabled, as the agent does not support SSL to the proxy but unencrypted traffic to the collector. This additional security prevents you from misconfiguring the agent assuming the metrics are as well encrypted end-to-end when they are not.

title: Configuration
body: ssl_verify_certificate: Determines whether the agent will verify the certificate presented by the proxy.

title: Configuration
body: This option is configured independently of the top-level ssl_verify_certificate parameter. This option is enabled by default. If the provided certificate is not correct, this option can cause the connection to the proxy server to fail.

title: Configuration
body: ca_certificate: The path to the CA certificate for the proxy server. If ssl_verify_certificate is enabled, the CA certificate must be signed appropriately.

title: Examples
body: Examples

title: No SSL
body: The following example shows no SSL connection between the agent and the proxy server as well as between the proxy server and the collector.

title: No SSL
body:
collector_port: 6667
ssl: false
http_proxy:
 proxy_host: squid.yourdomain.com
 proxy_port: 3128
 ssl: false

title: SSL Between Proxy and Collector
body: In this example, SSL is enabled only between the proxy server and the collector.

title: SSL Between Proxy and Collector
body:
collector_port: 6443
ssl: true
ssl_verify_certificate: true
http_proxy:
 proxy_host: squid.yourdomain.com
 proxy_port: 3128

title: SSL
body: The following example shows SSL is enabled between the agent and the proxy server as well as between the proxy server and the collector.

title: SSL
body:
collector_port: 6443
ssl: true
http_proxy:
 proxy_host: squid.yourdomain.com
 proxy_port: 3129
 ssl: true
 ssl_verify_certificate: true
 ca_certificate: /usr/proxy/proxy.crt

title: SSL with Username and Password
body: The following configuration instructs the agent to connect to a proxy server located at squid.yourdomain.com on port 3128. The agent will request the proxy server to establish an HTTP tunnel to the Sysdig collector at collector-your.sysdigcloud.com on port 6443. The agent will authenticate with the proxy server using the given user and password combination.

title: SSL with Username and Password
body:
collector: collector-your.sysdigcloud.com
collector_port: 6443
http_proxy:
	proxy_host: squid.yourdomain.com
	proxy_port: 3128
	proxy_user: sysdig_customer
	proxy_password: 12345
 ssl: true
	ssl_verify_certificate: true
	ca_certificate: /usr/proxy/proxy_cert.crt

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: The Sysdig agent generates log entries in /opt/draios/logs/draios.log. The agent will rotate out the log file when it reaches 10MB in size, keeping the 10 most recent log files archived with a date-stamp appended to the filename.

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: In order of increasing detail, the log levels available are: [ none | error | warning | info | debug | trace ].

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: The default level (info) creates an entry for each aggregated metrics transmission to the backend servers, once per second, in addition to entries for any warnings and errors.

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: Setting the value lower than info may prohibit troubleshooting agent-related issues.

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: The type and amount of logging can be changed by adding parameters and log level arguments shown below to the agent's user settings configuration file here:

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: /opt/draios/etc/dragent.yaml

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: After editing the dragent.yaml file, restart the agent at the shell with: service dragent restart to affect changes.

title: Change Agent Log Level
body: Note that dragent.yaml code can be written in both YAML and JSON. The examples below use YAML.

title: File Log Level
body: When troubleshooting agent behavior, increase the logging to debug for full detail:

title: File Log Level
body:
log:
 file_priority: debug

title: File Log Level
body: If you wish to reduce log messages going to the /opt/draios/logs/draios.log file, add the log: parameter with one of the following arguments under it and indented two spaces: [ none | error | warning | info | debug | trace ]

title: File Log Level
body:
log:
 file_priority: error

title: Container Console Logging
body: If you are running the containerized agent, you can also reduce container console output by adding the additional parameter console_priority:with the same arguments [ none | error | warning | info | debug | trace ]

title: Container Console Logging
body:
log:
 console_priority: warning

title: Container Console Logging
body: Note that troubleshooting a host with less than the default 'info' level will be more difficult or not possible. You should revert to 'info' when you are done troubleshooting the agent.

title: Container Console Logging
body: A level of 'error' will generate the fewest log entries, a level of 'trace' will give the most, 'info' is the default if no entry exists.

title: Example in dragent.yaml
body:
customerid: 831f3-Your-Access-Key-9401
tags: local:sf,acct:eng,svc:websvr
log:
 file_priority: warning
 console_priority: info

title: Example in dragent.yaml
body: OR

title: Example in dragent.yaml
Docker run command
body: If you are using the "ADDITIONAL_CONF" parameter to start a Docker containerized agent, you would specify this entry in the Docker run command:

title: Docker run command

-e ADDITIONAL_CONF=“log: { file_priority: error, console_priority: none }”
-e ADDITIONAL_CONF="log:\n file_priority: error\n console_priority: none"

title: Agent Auto-Config
body: Agent Auto-Config

title: Introduction
body: If you want to maintain centralized control over the configuration of your Sysdig agents, one of the following approaches is typically ideal:

title: Introduction
body: Via an orchestration system, such as using Kubernetes or Mesos/Marathon.Agent Install: Mesos Marathon DCOS

title: Introduction
body: Using a configuration management system, such as Chef or Ansible.

title: Introduction
body: However, if these approaches are not viable for your environment, or to further augment your Agent configurations via central control, Sysdig Monitor provides an Auto-Config option for agents. The feature allows you to upload fragments of YAML configuration to Sysdig Monitor that will be automatically pushed and applied to some/all of your Agents based on your requirements.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: Independent of the Auto-Config feature, typical Agent configuration lives in /opt/draios/etc and is derived from a combination of base config in the dragent.default.yaml file and any overrides that may be present in dragent.yaml. See also Understanding the Agent Config Files.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: Agent Auto-Config adds a middle layer of possible overrides in an additional file dragent.auto.yaml.When present, the the order of config application from highest precedence to lowest now becomes:

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: dragent.yaml

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: dragent.auto.yaml

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: dragent.default.yaml

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: While all Agents are by default prepared to receive and make use of Auto-Config data, the file dragent.auto.yaml will not be present on an Agent until you've pushed central Auto-Config data to be applied to that Agent.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: Auto-Config settings are performed via Sysdig Monitor's REST API. Simplified examples are available that use the Python client library to get or set current Auto-Config settings. Detailed examples using the REST API are shown below.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: The REST endpoint for Auto-Config is /api/agents/config. Use the GET method to review the current configuration. The following example shows the initial empty settings that result in no dragent.auto.yaml files being present on your Agents.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body:
curl -X GET \
 --header "Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx" \
 https://app.sysdigcloud.com/api/agents/config
 
 
Output:
{
 "files": []
}

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: Use the PUT method to centrally push YAML that will be distributed and applied to your Agents as dragent.auto.yaml files. The content parameter must contain syntactically-correct YAML. The filter option is used to specify if the config should be sent to one agent or all of them, such as in this example to globally enable Debug logging on all Agents:

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: Alternatively, the filter can specify a hardware MAC address for a single Agent that should receive a certain YAML config. All MAC-specific configs should appear at the top of the JSON object and are not additive to any global Auto-Config specified with "filter": "*" at the bottom. For example, when the following config is applied, the one Agent that has the MySQL app check configured would not have Debug logging enabled, but all others would.MySQL

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: To update the active central Auto-Config settings, simply PUT a complete replacement JSON object.

title: Enable Agent Auto-Config
body: All connected Agents will receive centrally-pushed Auto-Config updates that apply to them based on the filter settings. Any Agent whose Auto-Config is enabled/disabled/changed based on the centrally-pushed settings will immediately restart, putting the new configuration into effect. Any central Auto-Config settings that would result in a particular Agent's Auto-Config remaining the same will not trigger a restart.

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: To clear all Agent Auto-Configs, use the PUTmethod to upload the original blank config setting of '{ "files": [] }'.

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: It is also possible to override active Auto-Config on an individual Agent. To do so, follow these steps for your Agent:

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: Add the following config directly to the dragent.yaml file: auto_config: false.

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: Delete the file /opt/draios/etc/dragent.auto.yaml.

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: Restart the Agent.

title: Disable Agent Auto-Config
body: For such an Agent to opt-in to Auto-Config again, remove auto_config: false from the dragent.yaml and restart the Agent.

body: To prevent the possibility of pushing Auto-Config that would damage an Agent's ability to connect, the following keys will not be accepted in the centrally-pushed YAML.

title: Policies
body: This page introduces Sysdig policies and the rules that comprise them, providing the conceptual background needed to create, edit, and apply security policies in your own environment.

title: Understanding Sysdig Secure Policies
body: A Sysdig Secure policy is a combination of rules about activities an enterprise wants to detect in an environment, the actions that should be taken if the policy rule is breached, and-- potentially-- the notifications that should be sent. A number of policies are delivered out-of-the-box and can be used as-is, duplicated, or edited as needed. You can also create policies from scratch, using either predefined rules or creating custom rules.

title: Understanding Sysdig Secure Rules
body: Rules are the fundamental building blocks you will use to compose your security policies. A rule is any type of activity that an enterprise would want to detect in its environment.

title: Understanding Sysdig Secure Rules
body: Rules can be expressed in two formats:

title: Understanding Sysdig Secure Rules
body: Falco rules syntax, which can be complex and layered. All the default rules delivered by Sysdig are Falco rules, and users can also create their own Falco rules.

title: Understanding Sysdig Secure Rules
body: Fast rules syntax, which is simply a list against which a match/not match condition is applied. All fast rules are user-defined. They are grouped into five types: Container Image, File System, Network, Process, and Syscall.

title: Understanding the Rules Library
body: The Rules Library includes all created rules which can be referenced in policies. Out of the box, it provides a comprehensive runtime security library with container-specific rules (and predefined policies) developed by Sysdig's threat-research teams, Falco's open-source community rules, and international security benchmarks such as CIS or MITRE ATT&CK.

body: Using Falco within Sysdig Secure

title: What is Falco
body: Falco is an open-source intrusion detection and activity monitoring project. Designed by Sysdig, the project has been donated to the Cloud Native Computing Foundation, where it continues to be developed and enhanced by the community. Sysdig Secure incorporates the Falco Rules Engine as part of its Policy and Compliance modules.

title: What is Falco
body: Within the context of Sysdig Secure, most users will interact with Falco primarily through writing or customizing the rules deployed in the policies for their environment.

title: What is Falco
body: Falco rules consist of a condition under which an alert should be generated and an output string to send with the alert.

title: Conditions
body: Falco rules use the Sysdig filtering syntax.

title: Conditions
body: (Note that much of the rest of the Falco documentation describes installing and using it as a free-standing tool, which is not applicable to most Sysdig Secure users.)

title: Conditions
body: Rule conditions are typically made up of macros and lists.

title: Conditions
body: Macros are simply rule condition snippets that can be re-used inside rules and other macros, providing a way to factor out and name common patterns.

title: Conditions
body: Lists are (surprise!) lists of items that can be included in rules, macros, or other lists. Unlike rules/macros, they can not be parsed as Sysdig filtering expressions.

title: Conditions
body: Behind the scenes, the falco_rules.yaml file contains the raw code for all the Falco rules in the environment, including Falco macros and lists.

title: Fast Rules
body: Fast rules provide for simple detections of processes, network connections, and other operations. For example:

title: Fast Rules
body: If this process is detected, alert me.

title: Fast Rules
body: Or

title: Fast Rules
body: If a network connection on x port is detected, alert me.

title: Fast Rules
body: Unlike Falco rules, the Fast rule types do not permit complex rule combinations, such as "If a connection on x port from y IP address is detected..."

title: Fast Rules
body: The five Fast Rule Types are described below.

title: Container Rules
body: These rules are used to notify if a specific image name is running in an environment.

title: File System Rules
body: These rules are used to notify if there is write activity to a specific directory/file.

title: Network Rules
body: These rules are used to:

title: Network Rules
body: Detect activity on ports outside a trusted list on a specific list

title: Network Rules
body: Notify in case of unexpected inbound/outbound connections

title: Process Rules
body: These rules are used to detect if a specific process, such as SSH, is running in a particular area of the environment.

title: Syscall Rules
body: The syscall rule type is almost never deployed in user-created policies; the definitions below are for information only.

title: Syscall Rules
body: These rules are used (internally) to:

title: Syscall Rules
body: Notify if a specific syscall happens in a list

title: Syscall Rules
body: Notify if a syscall outside this trusted list happens in the environment

body: Periodically, Sysdig releases new Falco Rules that provide additional coverage for new behaviors and adds exceptions for known good behaviors. This topic helps you install Falco Rules as a container in an on-prem deployment. title: Non-Airgapped Environment

title: Non-Airgapped Environment

title: Non-Airgapped Environment
body: Use the docker run to install the Falco Rules. For example:

title: Airgapped Environment
body: This section assumes that the installation machine does not have the network access to pull the image from the Docker hub.

body: Download the container image on a machine that is connected to the network:

title: Airgapped Environment

title: Airgapped Environment
body: Create an archive file for the image:

title: Airgapped Environment

body: Untar the image file:

title: Airgapped Environment

title: Airgapped Environment
body: It restores both images and tags.

title: Airgapped Environment

title: [Beta] Policy Advisor
body: Sysdig Secure has introduced a tool for enhanced Kubernetes security called the Policy Advisor. At this time, it is used exclusively for Kubernetes Pod Security Policies.

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: According to Kubernetes, "A Pod Security Policy [PSP] is a cluster-level resource that controls security-sensitive aspects of the pod specification. The PodSecurityPolicy objects define a set of conditions that a pod must run with in order to be accepted into the system, as well as defaults for the related fields."

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: See more here: Kubernetes PSP documentation.

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: With Sysdig's Kubernetes Policy Advisor, you can auto-generate Pod Security Policies and perform dry tests or "simulations" of them before you commit them to an environment. These features offer several benefits:

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: PSPs help enforce least-privilege to strengthen security

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: Auto-generation can significantly decrease the time spent configuring Kubernetes policies

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: Simulation tests help teams tune their PSPs to avoid false positives, and help them avoid breaking applications during PSP deployments

title: [Beta] Pod Security Policies (PSP)
body: This feature is available in the Enterprise tier of the Sysdig product. See https://sysdig.com/pricing for details, or contact sales@sysdig.com .

title: Understand the PSP Workflow
body: In general, you will generate a PSP, run a simulated test, review the results, tune the PSP as needed, then turn off the simulator and add the pod security policy to the actual deployment.

title: Prerequisites
body: Sysdig Secure v. 3.0+ and Sysdig Agent v. 93.0+ on Kubernetes

title: Prerequisites
body: You must enable Kubernetes Audit Logging in SysdigKubernetes Audit Logging

title: Terminology
body: Note that Kubernetes Pod Security Policies are not the same as standard Sysdig Secure Policies and will not be displayed on the regular Policies list page.

title: Steps
body: Typically, the workflow proceeds as follows:

title: Steps
body: Access the module under Policies > Pod Security Policies.

title: Steps
body: Create the Pod Security Policy rules to be tested: either upload an existing PSP or upload a yaml deployment file from which the tool will auto-generate the PSP contents.

title: Steps
body: Click Start Simulation.

title: Steps
body: Deploy the pods in the appropriate cluster in your environment. Because the Simulator is running, it will deploy as a dry test and trigger any resulting alerts.

title: Steps
body: Check the Simulation output and tweak the PSP content if needed.

title: Steps
body: When satisfied that the PSP rules perform as desired, click Stop Simulation.

title: Steps
body: You are now ready to apply this PSP to your cluster. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/policy/pod-security-policy/#enabling-pod-security-policies.

title: Kubernetes Dashboards
body: Kubernetes Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Highlights minimum, maximum, current, and desired replicas. Identify performance bottlenecks.Identify whether there are enough available pods compared to the desired pods.Use usage percentages over time to better estimate expansion capacity.Locate logical entities that are consuming too many cluster resources, or that are rapidly trending upwards towards unsustainable levels.Dive deeper into specific entities to identify the root cause of problems.Use usage percentages over time to better estimate expansion capacity. For example: A deployment with no available pods indicates that the corresponding app is not serving requests. Getting a dashboard on this condition means you can visualize the metrics and spring into action to find and resolve the issue quickly.Dropping the number of pods available and remaining below the desired number indicate that your application performance is degraded or not running at the redundancy required. With these metrics represented on the dashboard, you get a quick glance of the severity of the impact on your app's user experience.A lower number of replicas running during an extended period of time than the number of replicas desired indicates a symptom of entities not working properly, such as nodes or resources unavailability, Kubernetes or Docker Engine failure, broken Docker images, and so on. No replicas for a deployment object could potentially mean that the app is down.A continuous loop of pod restart (CrashLoopBackOff) might be associated with missing dependencies or unmet requirements, or insufficient resources. In CrashLoopBackOff, pods never get into ready status and therefore are counted as unavailable and down. Use these three dashboards to provide a high-level overview of all aspects of the Kubernetes environment's performance and resource saturation status.Set high-level alerts to narrow down areas of concern, before moving to the more in-depth dashboards.Quickly identify major performance issues within each type of entity.

title: Kubernetes Dashboards
body: Kubernetes Cluster and Node Capacity Highlights a comprehensive overview of the performance of the hosts or nodes that form the Kubernetes cluster, including CPU, memory, and file system usage, and network traffic. Before analyzing the Dashboard, consider the following guidelines related to resource usage: If Resource Limits is undefined for a container, Kubernetes does not default to a value.if Resource Requests is unspecified for a container, Kubernetes defaults to Limits if that is explicitly specified, otherwise to an implementation-defined value. Limits do not default to any value.If both Resource Limits and Resource Requests are not specified, no matter which value had been defaulted by Kubernetes, kube-state-metric (and hence Sysdig Monitor) reports zero. Therefore, only user-defined requested are reported by the kubernetes.pod.resourceRequests.memByte metric.The memory used by a container (the value returned by memory.used.bytes) can be greater than the memory requested by a pod (the value returned by kubernetes.pod.resourceRequests.memByte). This is permissible in Kubernetes because Requests value determines the minimum amount of resources required. For these reasons, it can be deduced that In some cases, the value of Used Resources will be more than that of Resource Requests and Resource Limits, and the value of Resource RequestS could be more than that of Resource Limit.The value of kubernetes.pod.resourceRequests.memByte<=memory.used.bytes<=kubernetes.pod.resourceLimits.memByte

body: Metric Type Metric type determines whether the metric value is a counter metric or a gauge metric. Sysdig Monitor offers two Metric types: Counter: The metric whose value keeps on increasing and is reliant on previous values. It helps you record how many times something has happened, for example, a user login. Gauge: Represents a single numerical value that can arbitrarily fluctuate over time. title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Steps Description

title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Decide What to monitor Determine what type of problem you want to be alerted on. See Alert Types to choose a type of problem.

title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Define how it will be monitored Specify exactly what behavior triggers a violation. For example, Marathon App is down on the Kubernetes Cluster named Production for ten minutes.

title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Decide Where to monitor Narrow down your environment to receive fine-tuned results. Use Scope to choose an entity that you want to keep a close watch on. Specify additional segments (entities) to give context to the problem. For example, in addition to specifying a Kubernetes cluster, add a namespace and deployment to refine your scope.

title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Define when to notify Define the threshold and time window for assessing the alert condition. Single Alert fires an alert for your entire scope, while Multiple Alert fires if any or every segment breach the threshold at once. Multiple Alerts include all the segments you specified to uniquely identify the location and thus provides full qualification of where the problem occurred. The higher the number of segments the easier to uniquely identify the affected entities. A good analogy for multiple alerts is alerting on cities. For example, creating multiple alerts on San Francisco would trigger an alert which will include information such as the country that it is part of is the USA and the continent is North America. Trigger gives you control over how notifications are created. For example, you may want to receive a notification for every violation, or want only a single notification for a series of consecutive violations.

title: Guidelines for Creating Alerts
body: Decide how notifications are sent Alert supports customizable notification channels, including email, mobile push notifications, OpsGenie, Slack, and more. To see supported services, see Set Up Notification Channels.Set Up Notification Channels

title: Process Filter
body: container.image Matches if the process is running inside a container running the specified image - include: container.image: luca3m/prometheus-java-app

title: Process Filter
body: kubernetes.<object>.annotation.* kubernetes.<object>.label.* Matches if the process is attached to a Kubernetes object (Pod, Namespace, etc.) that is marked with the Annotation/Label matching the given value. Note: This pattern does not apply to the Docker-only command-line shown above, but would instead apply if the exporter were installed as a Kubernetes Deployment using this example YAML. Note: See Kubernetes Objects, below, for information on the full set of supported Annotations and Labels. - include: kubernetes.pod.annotation.prometheus.io/scrape: true

body: process.name Matches the name of the running process - include: process.name: java

title: Process Filter

title: Process Filter
body: port Matches if the process is listening on one or more TCP ports. The pattern for a single rule can specify a single port as shown in this example, or a single range (e.g.8079-8081), but does not support comma-separated lists of ports/ranges. Note: This parameter is only used to confirm if a process is eligible for scraping based on the ports on which it is listening. For example, if a process is listening on one port for application traffic and has a second port open for exporting Prometheus metrics, it would be possible to specify the application port here (but not the exporting port), and the exporting port in the conf section (but not the application port), and the process would be matched as eligible and the exporting port would be scraped. - include: port: 8080

title: Process Filter
body: appcheck.match Matches if an Application Check with the specific name or pattern is scheduled to run for the process.Integrate Applications (Default App Checks) - exclude: appcheck.match: "*"

title: conf
body: Parameter name Description Example

title: conf
body: port Either a static number for a single TCP port to be scraped, or a container/Kubernetes Label name or Kubernetes Annotation specified in curly braces. If the process is running in a container that is marked with this Label or is attached to a Kubernetes object (Pod, Namespace, etc.) that is marked with this Annotation/Label, scraping will be attempted only on the port specified as the value of the Label/Annotation. Note: The Label/Annotation to match against will not include the text shown in red. Note: See Kubernetes Objectsfor information on the full set of supported Annotations and Labels. Note: If running the exporter inside a container, this should specify the port number that the exporter process in the container is listening on, not the port that the container exposes to the host. port: 8080 - or - port: "{container.label.io.prometheus.port}" - or - port: "{kubernetes.pod.annotation.prometheus.io/port}"

title: conf
body: port_filter A set of include and exclude rules that define the ultimate set of listening TCP ports for an eligible process on which scraping may be attempted. Note that the syntax is different from the port pattern option from within the higher-level include rule in the process_filter. Here a given rule can include single ports, comma-separated lists of ports (enclosed in square brackets), or contiguous port ranges (without brackets). port_filter: - include: 8080 - exclude: [9092,9200,9300] - include: 9090-9100

title: conf
body: path Either the static specification of an endpoint to be scraped, or a container/Kubernetes Label name or Kubernetes Annotation specified in curly braces. If the process is running in a container that is marked with this Label or is attached to a Kubernetes object (Pod, Namespace, etc.) that is marked with this Annotation/Label, scraping will be attempted via the endpoint specified as the value of the Label/Annotation. If path is not specified, or specified but the Agent does not find the Label/Annotation attached to the process, the common Prometheus exporter default of /metrics will be used. Note: A Label/Annotation to match against will not include the text shown in red. Note: See Kubernetes Objects for information on the full set of supported Annotations and Labels. path: "/prometheus" - or - path: "{container.label.io.prometheus.path}" - or - path: "{kubernetes.pod.annotation.prometheus.io/path}"

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: app_checks_always_send: true/false Legacy config that causes the agent to emit any process with app check. With process filtering, this translates to an extra "include" clause at the head of the process filter which matches a process with any app check, thereby overriding any exclusions. Still subject to limit.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: flush_filter: Definition of process filter to be used if flush_filter_enabled == true. Defaults to -include all

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: flush_filter_enabled: true/false Defaults to false (default process reporting behavior). Set to true to use the rest of the process filtering options.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: limit: N (chosen number) Defines the approximate limit of processes to emit to the backend, within 10 processes or so. Default is 250 processes.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: top_n_per_container: N (chosen number) Defines how many of the top processes per resource category per emitted container to report after included processes. Still subject to limit. Defaults to 1.

title: Process Condition Parameters and Rules
body: top_n_per_host: N (chosen number) Defines how many of the top processes per resource category per host are reported before included processes. Still subject to limit. Defaults to 1.

title: Usage
body: Variables Description

title: Usage
body: DEPLOY_HOSTNAME The server that hosts the Sysdig API endpoints. The default is https://secure.sysdig.com.

title: Usage
body: DEPLOY_USER_NAME The username for the account that has the admin-level access to the Sysdig API endpoints. The value defaults to a meaningless user, nobody@nobody.com.

title: Usage
body: DEPLOY_USER_PASSWORD The password for the admin user. The value defaults to a meaningless password nopassword.

title: Usage
body: VALIDATE_RULES If set to yes, ensure that the rules file is compatible with your user rules file. Otherwise, skip this validation step. The value defaults to yes.

title: Usage
body: DEPLOY_RULES If set to yes, the falco rules file is deployed. Otherwise, skip deploying the falco rules file. The value defaults to yes.

title: Usage
body: CREATE_NEW_POLICIES If set to yes, create new policies for any Falco rules that do not map to a policy. The value defaults is no.

title: Usage
body: SDC_SSL_VERIFY If set to false, allow certificate validation failures when deploying the rules. The value defaults to true.
